We're going to start with a glute max, because that's the most obvious one of the ones that most people are focusing their time on in the gym. Your glute max runs from your sacrum, and your thoracolumbar fascia, which is essentially this big piece of connective tissue. And it comes down, and it attaches onto what's called your IT band, or your iliotibial band, which is another big piece of connective tissue, and it runs down, and crosses your knee joint. So that's one attachment. It also comes down, and it attaches onto the outer portion of your thigh. So when people are talking about glutes, most often they're talking about their glute max. So now let's take a look at the glute meat. Craig, if you can give me a quarter turn here. A lot of times, people don't hear about the glute made or the glute min, because they are deeper muscles. You can't see them, so most people think they're not important. But your glute meat is actually a very critical stabilizer of your hip and your thigh. So your glute meat, if you can imagine, runs along the top of your iliot crest here, or the top of your hip bone, comes down, and it attaches onto your outer thigh. Even deeper to that is your glute min, and it's a very small muscle right here on the outer portion of your hip, and it also comes down and attaches onto the outer portion of your thigh. So don't forget, when you're training your legs, when you're training your hips, you've got three glute muscles, glute max, glute medius, and glute menimus. Next, muscle group, we're going to talk about called your adductors. Now, a lot of people maybe aren't familiar with these, or they don't realize just how important these small muscle groups are. So you actually got five adductors muscles that we're going to cover here today. All of them start on what's called your pubis, or if you can imagine kind of the inside of your hip, that's where your pubis is. So they all come off this pubis and come down and attach to the inside of your thigh. So the first one is called your pectinius. It comes down and across and attaches to the top of your thigh. Second, you have what's called your adductor brevis, and brevis just means short, so it comes down and across and attaches below the pectinius. Third, you have your adductor longus, so again, running from the pubis comes down. So you guys can imagine how these are almost layered in fashion. Fourth, and one I want you guys to make note of, the adductor magnets. It's probably the biggest adductor. It runs from your pubis, comes down and it attaches not only to the inside of your thigh, but a little bit lower down as well. And that makes your adductor magnets quite unique. Last but not least, you've got a long skinny muscle, called your grisillus. And it runs from your pubis, come all the way down and attaches to the tibia, or the inside of your lower leg bone. So we covered five big adductor muscles, pectinius, adductor brevis, adductor longus, adductor magnets, and grisillus. And what's important, I don't want you guys to confuse these with the quads or the hamstrings. They're absolutely important for bulk and width, front to back side to side of your thighs, but they are unique. And we're going to make sure that we try and use some exercises to develop these muscles in their own right. Last but not least, we're going to look at the calves or the lower leg muscles. I'm going to have Craig go ahead and turn around here, and there's essentially two muscle groups that were interested in developing. Your gastrocnemius and your solius. With your gastrocnemius, it's unique because it crosses your knee joint. So you have what's called a lateral head of your gastrocnemius, and you also have a medial head. And both of those heads converge or come down and attach to your Achilles tendon. Deep to that gastrocnemius, you have what's called your solius. And your solius attaches to your tibia and your fibula, those two lower leg bones, and it also comes down and attaches onto the Achilles tendon. So two muscles, one crosses the knee, but both attach to the Achilles tendon and help create planar flexion, which we'll talk a little bit more about. Later on. So we've covered a lot of ground in this video. Five big muscle groups and 17 individual muscles. Just as a quick recap, you got your calves. You got your hamstring, the big muscles on the back of your thigh. You got your glutes or your butt muscles for lack of a better turn. If we spin Craig around, you got your quad, the big guys on the front of the thigh, and then it turns his thigh out. We're just a little bit. You get a good look at the ad after some of those inner thigh muscles. So we spin a lot of time covering the muscles. Now let's jump into the bones and joints involved in creating all these different movements. Now that we've covered the muscular anatomy, let's take a look at the individual bones and joints that work together in your lower body and your hip. To create motion. The first bone that I want to talk about is called your pelvis. And if you imagine on both sides of your body, you've got a pelvis and it kind of works like a bowl to shape and tie everything together. So your pelvis is a really critical structure. Within your pelvis, coming on down, you've got your femur or your big thigh bone. Working our way down even further, you've got your big lower leg bone, which is called your tibia. And that's kind of the media of the two. It's right here in the front. And last but not least, you've got this smaller bone called your fibula. And while most people don't talk about it, it only absorbs about 10% of your body weight. So when most people are talking about their lower leg, they're typically talking about the tibia versus the fibula. Now that you have a better understanding of the bones, let's see how they all work together to create joints which will help us create movement. I'm going to have Craig go ahead and give me a quarter turn again. And when you think about your pelvis, it's really simple. It's got two basic motions. It's got what's called anterior tilt or rolling the hips forward. And it's got what's called posterior tilt, where he rolls the hips back and underneath it. So the pelvis is fairly straightforward. But from there, you've got your hip joint. And your hip is essentially your thigh bone coming into this socket here. So it's what's called a ball and socket joint. And at that ball and socket joint, you have tons of freedom of motion. If you can imagine, you can do all these different movements. So Craig can flex his hip. He can extend his hip, AB ducted, AD ducted, internally and externally rotate. So that's important to note, hip joint. It's a centerpiece for your body because it has so much mobility. Moving down, you got your knee joint. And a lot of people would call your knee joint a hinge joint. But that's kind of a misnomer. It's actually what's called a condoloid joint. So you can go ahead and give me a quarter turn here, Craig. Condoloid means it's got a little bit of rotation. It's necessary to note, but it's not necessarily true of what you're going to be training in the gym. Primarily, when you're thinking about your knee, you've got knee flexion or pulling your leg back like you would in a hamstring curl. And you've got knee extension, like you would in a squat, a deadlift or a leg extension. Last but not least, if we come down to your ankle joint. Your ankle primarily has two basic motions. It's got what's called planar flexion, like you would when you come up on your toes to do a calf raise. And you have what's called doorcy flexion. And that's where you would pull your toes back up towards your face. So far, we've covered the muscles, the bones, and the joints that are on-volved in creating movement through your hips, your thighs, and your lower leg. So you guys can see what this is going to look like in the gym using these muscles for real function. If you recall, your quad, you've got four quad muscles. But what is unique? And that actually runs from your hip comes down and crosses your knee. So, rectus femurus is there because it can help you flex your hip as you would in a step up, or even if you're going to the track and you're doing some sprinting for your conditioning work, that's where you're going to see rectus femurus being used. But more importantly, in the function that most people are probably most familiar with is knee extension. So you're going to see this anytime you're in the gym if you're doing like a leg extension or something of that nature, that's where you're going to see the quads. And then on a big compound lift like you would in a squat or something of that nature. Anytime you're squatting, that's where you're going to extend the knee and bring out those quads. So your quads are those big muscles on the front of the thighs. Now let's spin Craig around and we're going to look at the back. Remember your hamstrings cross two joints. They cross your hip and they cross your knee. So there's got two primary functions that we're going to hit when we're in the gym. The first is hip extension. So as you recall, hamstrings come down, they cross the knee. Now let's talk about glutes. When we're talking about glutes, most people think hip extension. One exception, your adductor magnus is a really big muscle. First, choose your weight and sit on the leg extension machine with your legs under the pad and your hands holding the sidebars. This will be your starting position. You'll need to adjust the pads so that it fits snug on top of your lower legs. Make sure your legs form a 90-degree angle between your lower and upper leg. Using your quadriceps, exhale and extend your legs while the rest of your body remains stationary on the seat. Pause a second in the contracted position, then inhale and slowly lower the weight back to the original position.

To perform this exercise, sit down at the leg press machine and place your legs on the platform directly in front of you with the shoulder width stance. Lower the safety bar holding the weighted platform in place and press the platform into your legs are fully extended in front of you. Do not lock your knees. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and slowly lower the platform until your upper and lower legs form a 90 degree angle. Now driving mainly with the heel of your foot, push the platform back to the starting position.

Legbris is one of the best exercises to build your lower body, but you need to know how various foot positions target the different muscles of your legs. Number one, low foot position. This is a great way to emphasize your parts in the legbris. When you place your feet lower on the back, there is a higher degree of knee pain. When your hamstrings are almost touching your calves in the bottom position. This is what leads to the maximum brother situation. Next, high foot position. This is the best way to target your boots in the legbris. When you place the feet higher on the back, you'll notice that the degree of hip pain is more than the knee pain in the bottom position. It results in the most tension being placed on the boots instead of the quads. Lastly, wide foot position. This can be a great way to bias your adactors in the movement. A wider foot stance with the toes pointing outwards allows you to easily co-deeper in the end range of motion. This is where the adactors are the most active out of all the other muscles. Keep these dry and you'll feel the difference right away.

And today's workout we are focusing on legs. We're focusing on the entire lower body here. We're working our quads. We're working our hamstrings. We're working our glutes. The only thing we're not directly training in this workout today is our calves. But keep in mind that you work your calves indirectly by doing awesome exercises that we're doing today like jump squats, walking lunges and step ups. In today's workout we're going to do seven exercises. We're starting with squats. Then we're moving into the leg press. Barbell, hip thrusts, walking lunges. Moving into sumo stance, Romanian dead lifts, Bulgarian split squats in the Smith finishing off with weighted steps. Your rest period should be no more than 60 seconds and the entire workout should take you about an hour and 15 minutes including your warm-up. Okay, so let's get going with this leg workout. One of the biggest setbacks in getting results from your squats is having weak glutes and or tight hip flexors. So I always make sure to do a lot of hip mobility stretches and hip flexor stretches before I start my squats. So we're going to get a mat. We're going to get on all fours and we're going to do a fire hydrant stretch which also opens the hips up. Starting with the left side, you're going to lift the knee up and you're going to go in a forward circle with your entire leg. Keeping your hips steady and parallel to the floor. Then you'll put that knee down and do the exact same thing on the right leg. Once you're done with that you want to do it all over again but switch the direction of the circle that you're moving your knees. On each leg you'll do 10 circles in each direction. From that exact position we're going to move right into a hip flexor stretch. You're going to bring one foot out into a kneeling lunge position and really push the opposite loop forward getting a really good stretch on your hip flexor. You'll do that for about 30 seconds on each leg twice. Now that our hips are open and our hip flexors feel nice and loose and stretched right here to go we're going to move into our warm upsets of our squats. I always start with the bar only. I do two sets of 10 reps. In between those sets I like to do jump squats. The point of doing the jump squats in between is it really gets the blood flowing, gets your joints lubricated and gets the nervous system really circulating so that you're ready for the weight of the squats. The next two warm upsets I'm going to add a moderate weight for me it's 10 pounds on each side of the bar. You do it right for you. I do two more sets of 10 reps. Now we're ready for the working sets. We're going to add the correct weight that allows you to get to three sets of 10 reps with perfect form. I like to set the bar not right on top of my shoulders but right below my shoulders resting on my upper traps. Step back get your core activated, get your feet perfectly parallel to one another, your toes pointed straight ahead and your feet are going to be placed anywhere between hip width and shoulder width distance. When you feel steady you're going to pop your butt back, archer lower back and go down into the squat. Make sure your knees are staying right over your toes and not wobbling right in left. Knees to ability is really important for perfect forming your squats. Look straight ahead, keep your chest lifted and go down just as far as you can in order to activate your glutes and rise back up the same way you came out. In my head when I'm doing my own squats, when I get to the bottom of the squat, I like to keep the weight in my heel so that I really dig those heels into the ground and drive up for my squat with those heels and that will definitely help you keep the tension in the glutes and really build muscle on that area. Moving into exercise two, we're going to do four sets of 15 reps on the leg press. And what's unique about this exercise is we're really going to focus on building our quad on this leg press move instead of the regular glutes or hamstrings that you're used to seeing on the leg press. We're going to grab a weight that's a little lighter than usual. Every machine is different so make sure you test it out do a couple of warm upsets and make sure you're choosing a weight that isn't too heavy. You want to go a little bit lighter on this because you want to focus on form. So what you do is you get into the leg press and you bring your heels as low down on the platform as you can. Your heels are together at the bottom of the platform and your toes are pointed out. As you bring the leg press down, you're going to make sure that your knees are pointed in the exact direction of your toes. So what I'm doing with this exercise is focusing on tempo. So as you bring the weight down in your head you're going to do a count to three. It's one one thousand two one thousand three one thousand. When the weight is at the bottom you're going to give it a two count so one one thousand two thousand. As soon as that two seconds is up you push the weight back up nice and slow one one thousand two one thousand three one thousand. You rest very quickly without locking your knees and start all over again. As you bring the weight down and push it back up the weight is going to be in the balls of your feet. You're not your toes but really in the balls of your feet. You're going to bring that weight down and your heels won't even be on the platform whatsoever and that is what's going to turn all of the tension into your quads. Moving into exercise three we're going to do four sets of 12 to 15 reps of barbell hip thrusts. This is one of my favorite exercises and one of my all-time greatest moves for building up those glutes. It also works your hamstrings with a foot position that I use. I like to do it the way I'm showing you right now in the rack because ladies it shows you that you do not have to have a spotter and you actually can use a heavier weight. All you need to do is grab a bench from inside the gym and set the rack to the same height as the bench. This setup will allow you to un-rack and re-rack the barbell without needing a spotter. When doing barbell hip thrust you want to make sure that the barbell is right across your hips and that you set your feet so that the back of your knees are at a 90 degree angle your heels are a little bit close together and your toes are just slightly pointed out. As you lift the weight up you will squeeze your glutes and as you lower the weight you'll have a slight anterior tilt to your hips and then when you bring the barbell back up you'll have a posterior tilt and squeeze your glutes and hold it at the top there for just a second before repeating the rep. The next exercise is the walking lunge. We're going to do four sets of 24 total steps which is 12 steps on each side. What you need to focus on while you're doing this exercise is nice, slow and controlled reps. Do not use momentum to be in a hurry as you're doing your walking lunges. I like to take every single step and at the top I collect myself. I actually sometimes put my foot down and then take another step with the next leg. In doing that it allows me to make sure that I am going straight down and straight up instead of leaning forward and activating all the wrong muscles. Taking a little bit more of a shallow step during your walking lunges it allows you to use the heel of the front leg to really drive up and that will help you focus on the glute and the hamstring of the front leg. The next exercise is a sumo stance Romanian for this exercise we're going to do four sets of 12 to 15 reps. I like using the sumo stance during my Romanian delips because it allows me to just slightly shift the focus of the muscle being worked. By doing a sumo stance you move the focus a little bit to the adactors which is the inner thigh instead of having such focus on the glutes and the back of the hamstrings. A tip I like to share for Romanian delus is to start the movement by tilting your hips and really moving that butt backward. I like this a lot because most glute and leg workouts focus on the up and down movement and this really focuses on the backward and forward movement which is really really crucial to building up the glutes. The next exercise is Bulgarian split squats. We're going to do three sets of 10 reps. When you're getting set up for Bulgarian split squats I like to get my body under the bar and put my heels directly under my hips that sets you up for good form right from the start. From there I take the working leg and I take a small step forward about one foot distance. Once your foot is in that position you're going to take the back leg and place it on the bench behind you. As you move down into the squat you want to focus on keeping your knee right above your ankle do not let your knee go beyond your toes so take a peek down at any time during this movement and make sure that your knee is right above your ankle. Look in the mirror if you can and make sure that your knee again stays really steady and that there's no right left movement. It's really important that that knee working alone is really strong in steady. As you move down you want to focus on keeping the weight in your heel. Keep that weight in the heel as you drive back up and that'll make sure that you're working a hamstring and the glue on that leg. Our last exercise in today's leg workout is the weighted step up. We're going to do three sets of 15 reps on each leg. You want to make sure that you find a bench or a box that's about knee height. You don't want the box to be too short otherwise you won't get the depth and the range of motion that you need for this exercise. Grab a moderate weight that allows you to control your balance as you're stepping up and down off of the box. As you step up onto the box drive with your heel. Make sure all the weight is in that heel and again that will focus on using the glue and the hamstring and the quad of that working leg. When you get to the top of the box I like to stop just briefly to collect my balance. I do this with this exercise and my lunges. It allows you to just make sure that you're using perfect form throughout the entire movement. Step back very slowly and I do all reps on one leg before I switch to the other one. This workout is great. If you only have time to train legs once a week it works all of the major muscles and the lower half of the body. So why would we want to do blood flow restriction? Is it better than regular training? Is it worse than regular training? The research suggests that blood flow restriction is basically as good as the normal heavy training. So people say, well, why would you do it? Well, the reason you'd want to do blood flow restriction is you can use much less weight. You can use really light weights and still get the same hypertrophy effects as you can with heavy weights. So obviously, for somebody like me who's doing heavy squats, heavy bench, heavy dead lifts, and is pretty destroyed by the time they get through their main lifts. So any upper body work you're always going to wrap at the top of the arm. For any lower body work you're always going to wrap at the top of the thigh. Regardless of what you're working, for upper body work, I prefer a smaller cuff like a crickly medical attorney. There's some scientific evidence that the area that the cuff covers does not get the benefits from BFR. So you want as minimal a cuff as you can get for a smaller limb. After holding the top contracted position for a brief moment, inhale and slowly lower the bar back down to the starting position.

So our next exercise will be the crunch. The crunch is something that everyone feels they absolutely have down. Everyone says, oh man, I know the crunch is an easy one, but it is probably the exercise I see screwed up the most in the gym to be quite honest. It's actually a very advanced movement and I rarely see it done properly without compromising safety, health or your neck or your spine. So I'm going to get down there and show you what we see basically in daily basis. So I'm going to bend my legs, flat back position. So people get down in the mat. They think they go to do some crunches. They put their hands behind their head and they know they got to get a lot of crunches because if I do 500 crunches that means I'm going to be ripped, so I'm going to go here. And I didn't feel anything and not only that, but I'm compromising several different joints of my body and I'm actually wasting my time. So what I'd rather see is, you know, heels down, push your back into the mat, spread your hands. Pulling, I prefer your hands not to be even on the back of your neck more to the side. So what I have here is the pubic bone, the zipoid process and all I'm going to do is shorten those lines. As a matter of fact, you're probably not going to see too much movement. It's going to be minimal and what you see is a basic contraction within my abdomen. So I'm here. I come up, squeeze hole, shorten those lines, down slowly. Come up, squeeze hole, down slowly. Yeah, I would say mental strength is definitely at the core of my principles just because of what I mentioned earlier. A lot of people like to get caught up in the, oh, I want the six pack. I want the biceps. I want the quads. I want the back. And all of that is cool. I'm not saying that that's, there's anything wrong with that. The back will come later. It's just, it's literally like a downman off-back. Once you get that mental fortitude down, everything else is just coming. I love that. What's your favorite movement and why? I get asked this so much either by other trainers or by people that come into my class. And I feel like it's not a movement in particular. It's more of a tool. I just really love kettlebells. And the reason I love kettlebells, because it's kind of like, for me, there's nothing better than a good kettlebell complex. Because I feel like it's a dance. And there's so much body control that is required. That you really, those who maybe aren't familiar with it, there's such a transferable feeling into stepping off of that corner block, or moving out of the way of that car, or taking that random step to get out of the way quickly. I feel like I get a lot of that out of kettlebells as well, whether it's a swing and just really having that control, and that activation to control the downward portion of it, etc. Yeah. Yeah. What's your advice for somebody who's just getting started? Good question. I feel like you have to have a solid why. If your why isn't solid, you're going to find it really easy to fall off of the train. And by train, I mean, whatever moment of it is you're carrying it to the next workout. A lot of people get caught up into like, momentary goals and what I mean by that is like, for example, let's say somebody's getting ready for a wedding, whether you're the one getting married or you're just attending a wedding of somebody else. You say, I want to lose a couple pounds because I want to fit into this dress. And there's absolutely nothing wrong with that, but the wedding does have a date. And then there's going to be a day where the weddings over. And so what did you just only exercise because you wanted to fit into this dress? Now that the wedding's over is like, what are you doing now? I feel like unless you have a solid why to hold as your foundation, then you're going to find it really hard to keep going into the gym. So I feel like once you have a solid why, that'll just keep you going into the next session. So whether you want to be, but a version of yourself, you want to improve your health for your family, you're going up an age and you feel like you want to start moving around with a little bit more fluidity. Even though a balanced diet can provide you with nutrients, sometimes you need more that you can't typically obtain from foods like vitamin D. With a multivitem because the X-y are essential nutrients, food or beverage or a dietary supplement will have a nutrition-fax panel or a supplement-fax panel. And on the right-com, you'll see a percent DV or daily value. That tells you from that serving size or portion size, what percentage of your daily value of that need for that vitamin is present. Very few vitamins are needed above that to sustain or support metabolic performance. Exceptions to that would be perhaps vitamin C, vitamin D, maybe vitamin E. Those are needed perhaps in certain states or conditions in higher amounts. When you have a multivitemund product, it's almost always present your fine vitamins A, D, E, and K combined or at least A, D, and E. And those are all fat-scival vitamins. And because they're fat-scival, you need to consume them with a modest amount of fat at the same time to increase the amount of absorbed.

The broad jump has been explained me by a lot of personnel that has probably the most specific test there is. Horizontal power relates to so many things in football and that's really all it does. It's a true expression of horizontal power. The only rule really is when you go through the descent or the ascent of the jump before you're feet leaving ground, you can't shuffle your feet to get our main planet. And then once you jump out and your feet stick, you have to stick to land and you cannot fall backwards and you cannot fall forward either. The box broad jump, the broad jump just to get that pure expression of horizontal power, but at the same time, soft in the landing. The landing does go through an excessive joint load that you don't want to repeat over and over again. You want to be able to actually execute the form on a broad jump without the impact and the joint load of the landing. So what better way than the soft land by jumping up on the box is that simple. It's identical to the exercise we did for the vertical jump in terms of linear box jump. And for now we're going to take the box height down a little bit about this height and we're going to stand further back. So it's going to technically be a broad jump with height up onto the box. So a box this height, we're going to back up anywhere between three and five feet. So Mark has to have it going to demonstrate this one. Approximately three to four feet away. The position being about hip width apart, the arm starting up at the body fully erect in terms of the hips, the knees and the ankles have no bend in it. It's going to be a rapid arm action down with the hands clearing the hip. Then at the bottom of the deep knee bend you drive your arms forward. The hips will follow. Then you're going to be jumping up and on to the box. The only difference in the arm action is now after you come out of your D-cent and into your A-cent you're going to kind of put your arms out and up a little bit and let your hips just follow your arms up onto the box. Remember the arms will always lead the hips on the D-cent and up into the jumping action. Good. You know how his forward projection of his hips. So it's not necessarily just a vertical. Now we're looking for more horizontal plus vertical power. There's no correct progression. It's micro progression within what that person is able to do at that particular moment. So if they can safely land on a box, that is the proper distance. The I'd say on average we typically start people out about three feet away from the box and up onto about a 35 to 40 inch box. Then we micro-progress the box up and their distance back. Again arm action will lead the hips. Jump up and on to the box. Have you ever gone for a long intense run and by the time you got home, you were exhausted, not hungry and maybe even a little bit nauseous? If so, this video's for you. If you workout long enough at a high enough intensity, your workout can alter your hunger cues and leave you as for yourself, why am I not hungry the day I workout? This can happen for a couple of reasons. In increase in stomach acidity, particularly for those who have a history of acid reflux. A decrease in blood flow to the stomach as the blood is traveling to the muscle that's being used. And perhaps even a decrease in your hunger hormone. This small study found that growing your hunger hormone was lower in athletes who had exercise at a moderate to high intensity level compared to those who were sedentary. Therefore, causing these athletes to feel less hungry after their workout, which can then impact recovery time as most individuals will wait until their hungry to eat. My suggestion, take your closer look at how you're fueling your body. Are you eating enough carbs before your workout? If not, try to have some simple carbohydrates that just fruit 30 minutes before your workout. Is your high intensity workout longer than 60 minutes? If so, then you might need to supplement with carbohydrates during your workout, such as gel packs. And lastly, eat carbs and protein, post workout, emphasis on the carbohydrates. For example, you can have Greek yogurt with honey and chia seeds or maybe a protein shake with banana and oats. Try using trialan error to fuel your body during your workouts and monitor your progress through performance as well as hunger cues.

Plus, research shows that higher protein diets that are lower in carbohydrate actually work very well for fat loss, especially when we're trying to maintain your build. The muscle. There's a simple fact that it's very difficult for the body to take protein and then convert it into body fat. It's not impossible, but out of the three micronutrients, your body has to work much harder to take protein and convert that into body fat. The two main type of carbohydrates are your high glycemic or fast-adjusting carbohydrates. And then your low glycemic or slow digestive carbohydrates. And the reason that they're called high glycemic or low glycemic is the way that the body responds to them when you consume them. High glycemic carbs, like I said, sugars, white potatoes. When you eat them, your body processes them very rapidly. So they basically get broken down in the body and then absorbed by your intestines and get right into your bloodstream. And that raises your blood sugar levels, your blood glucose levels. They shoot up in the spikes in the levels. So those are your high glycemic carbs. That's not a great thing. To the flat bench, place a dumbbell on each side of it. Next place your right leg at the end of the bench and bend your torso forward from the waist until your upper body is parallel to the floor. Place your right hand on the other end of the bench for support. Now use your left hand to pick up the dumbbell and hold the weight while keeping your lower back straight. The palm of your hand should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position. From here, breathe out and pull the weight straight up to the side of your chest, keeping your upper arm close to your side while your torso is stationary. Focus on the back muscles when you reach the contracted position of this exercise. Also, make sure the lift is performed with the back muscles and not the arms. The forearms should do no other work besides holding the dumbbell. Now lower the weight back down to the starting position, breathing in as you perform this step. Place the switch sides and repeat the movement with the other arm.

So we've dumped that in. We've got, I think that was a teaspoon of baking powder. We've got a fourth of a teaspoon of salt. Connect the standard handle to a tower and if possible position the cable to shoulder height. If not, a low pulley will suffice. With your side to the cable, grab the handle with both hands and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arms length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. With your feet positioned, hip width apart and knees slightly bend. Hold the cable to the middle of your chest. This will be your starting position. Press the cable away from your chest, fully extending both arms. Your core should be tight and engaged. Hold the repetition for several seconds before returning to the starting position. At the conclusion of the set, repeat facing the other direction.

Hi guys, I'm Lai Stilion and I'll leave for her athlete and today I'm going to be taking you through my 21-minute at Home Leg Workout. I structured the circuit to give you a great leg workout that you can do anywhere with no equipment, but as a bonus you're also going to get a great cardio workout. This workout is structured as a circuit. We have six exercises and you'll be completing each exercise back to back for a minute total. That's one round and you'll be completing three rounds. With a minute rest between each round. Alright, so let's get to work. So the first exercise is the pop squat. Now remember you're going to be doing each exercise for one minute. To perform a pop squat, go down into a squat, tapping both hands to the floor. Jump up, bringing your feet together, and perform this continuously at a moderate pace for the full minutes. Reset and we're going to move into our second exercise with the Bulgarian split squats. We'll be performing this exercise all to four one minute, so that's 30 seconds on one leg and 30 seconds on the other. To perform the Bulgarian split squats, you'll need a platform to place your foot on, like a couch. Start by placing one foot behind you onto the platform. It may take you one or two reps to figure out where your foot placement is most comfortable. Try to keep all your weight on your front leg, push off of your heels and make sure you're keeping your knees in line with your ankles. As soon as you've completed 30 seconds with one leg, you immediately switch over to the other leg. The third exercise is a variation of the same exercise we just did. The plyometric Bulgarian split squat. The difference here is that when you're performing the exercise, instead of coming up slow and controlled, you want to explode up and actually come off the floor with one foot. And make sure when you come down, you land softly on your toes. And just like the previous exercise, when you're done completing 30 seconds on one leg, immediately switch over to the other leg. And the fourth exercise is what I like to call a one and a half squat. To perform a one and a half squat, squat all the way down, then come up halfway before squatting back down and coming all the way back down. The main reason I like to do them this way is to increase time under tension. Exercise 5 is the glute bridge. Just like all the other exercises in the circuit will be performing the glute bridge for a total of 1 minutes. To perform a glute bridge, lay on your back with your feet flat on the ground. Drag your hips up as you squeeze your glutes at the top. Pause for a second, then go back down and repeat. This is a great exercise for isolating your glutes. And we're wrapping up the circuit with the jump squat. For the jump squat, you're going to come down just like a bodyweight squat, but instead of coming up slow and controlled, you want to explode up, making sure your feet come off the ground. This is a great exercise to finish off the circuit because it not only burns out your legs, but gets your heart rate way up. Now remember, you're performing each round a total of three times. I would recommend you do this workout anytime you either can't make it to the gym, your short on time, or your traveling. The full workout breakdown is in the article below here on bodybuilding.com. If you have any questions for me, you can find me on Instagram at lieystylion, or on my website at lieystylionfitness.com. And for more free workouts and articles like this, keep coming back to bodybuilding.com. Lieyst, home workout, content, take one. Oh my God. This is my job. This is what I do. Okay.

With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position. Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees. Next comes the second pull. The main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-pack position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight. At the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back with the arms still extended. As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, pull yourself under the bar far enough that it can be racked onto the shoulders, rotating your elbows under the bars you do so. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

Position yourself on a preacher bench and grab the easy bar from the front barrest. Grab the easy bar at the close inner handle with the palms of your hands facing forward. They should also be slightly tilted inward due to the shape of the bar. With your upper arms and chest positioned against the preacher bench pad, hold the easy bar at shoulder level. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and slowly lower the bar until your upper arms are extended and your biceps are fully stretched. Then exhale and use your biceps to curl the weight back up until your biceps are fully contracted at the starting position. Squeeze the biceps and hold for a brief moment at the top contracted position to get the maximum benefit from this exercise.

Grab the pull-up bar with the palms of your hands facing forward. For a medium grip, your hands should be spaced as shoulder width. Both arms should be extended in front of you while holding the bar at the chosen grip. You'll want to bring your torso back about 30 degrees while creating a curvature in your lower back and sticking your chest out. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and pour your torso up until your head is above your hands. Retreat on squeezing your shoulder blades back and down as you reach the top contracted position. After a brief moment at the top contracted position, inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position with your arms extended and your lats fully stretched.

Clean the bar to shoulder height. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and lower your legs by bending your knees slightly. Then exhale and push through the heels of your feet to help propel the barbell upward. Simultaneously press up until your arms are fully extended and your legs are also straight. Finally inhale and lower the barbell back to the starting position.

When you span your life bringing the lab to the gym, there's no such thing as bro science. Hundreds of studies conducted thousands of articles written and techniques continuously tested. There are no variables, just results. I'm Dr. Jimst the Pani. Today's test workout is workout one, week one, and phase one of my 532 strength training program. Now this is a super heavy program that's going to take you to 10 weeks of very heavy way on the main exercises and will leave you stronger than you've ever been before. Now I'm about to start the test workout, but I want to remind you that heavy is just a relative term. A lot of people take when they hear heavy, it means they have to be bench pressing 350 and 400 foot up. Heavy is what's heavy to you. And during this workout, I'm not even going to be going that heavy just to show you that it's not about impressing anyone. It's about finding the proper weight that's going to allow you to get 5 reps for 5 sets. The first exercise is going to be the bench press. Here it's absolutely critical that you're hitting all 5 reps for all 5 sets. So that means on the first set, you're not going to go to absolute failure. You want to save something. The rest period is going to be somewhere in the 2 to 3 minute range, but the real heat to doing the bench press properly and safely is your upper arm position. You don't want your arms straight out forming a T. That's going to lead to shoulder problems. One thing that you can kind of visualize to do this is to think about holding grape fruits in your armpits. So you're actually going to be squeezing with your lats as you lower that bar down and keeping your arms in that proper position. Now the second exercise in this chest program is the incline bench press. Here you're going to be doing 3 sets of 6 to 8 reps. You're going to take an overhand grip a bit wider than shoulder width apart. What's different is where you lower the weight. Because the body is on an incline, now you're going to lower the weight more towards the upper or middle chest. You can't really go too low on the chest due to the incline of your upper body. So lower it down nice and slow to the upper chest. And again, you still want to explode the weight up nice and explosively back up over your upper chest. The third exercise in this chest workout is the flat dumbbell bench press. Here you're going to be doing 3 sets against 6 to 8 reps per set. Like with the incline bench press, this is an assistant exercise that is going to help you increase your strength on the barbell bench press. But also help the focus on muscle growth mainly the middle and lower peck area. Now with the dumbbell bench press, obviously you're using dumbbells which means each hand is moving independently of the other one. That's going to help increase the use of stabilizer muscles in the shoulder girdle that help. And that's going to help increase overall muscle strength when you get to that barbell bench press which you're using as your parometer of your upper strength on the chest for this program over the full 10 weeks. Incline dumbbell fly. This is an assistant exercise so you're doing 3 sets of 8 to 10 reps. Unlike the previous 3 exercises which will protect your joint exercises, this is a single joint exercise. Sometimes called an isolation exercise being on an incline helps the focus a bit more on the upper peck. Muscle fibers. Now to do the incline dumbbell fly, you're going to hold the dumbbells over your chest. Close together. You're going to keep a slight bend in the elbows. Bring your arms down as well as possible. Main chain is just that slight bend in the elbows. You're going to focus on using your chest to bring your arms back up and together in the top position. After the incline dumbbell fly, we move into abs. And the first ab exercise is your standard crunch. You're going to be doing 3 sets to muscle failure. One of the things about abs in reps speed is that most people think you need to really focus on slow and controlled reps. But with the crunch, research is shown that the faster and more explosive you do your crunches, the more of not only the abdominal muscles, but also the obliques that are used. You can rest as little as a minute to two minutes at the most for most of these ab exercises. The second ab exercise is the reverse crunch. This helps to focus more on the lower abs. You're going to do 3 sets to failure just like you did with the crunch. You're going to place your hands at your side to support your body or if you're using a bench, you could hold out for the bench. Start with your hips and your knees bent at 90 degrees. Then what you're going to do is use your lower abs to curl your hips up off the floor, bringing your knees toward your head. Then you're going to slowly lower it reverse to motion to lower your hips back to the floor. The third and final ab exercise is the obliques crunch. Here you're going to be doing 3 sets to failure just like with the other ab exercises. Here obviously is the name implies the focus is the obliques muscles. Then once you've done all reps to failure on one side, you're going to swing your knees over to the other side and then complete the reps just in the same manner. But on that side, again till muscle failure. So that's it for this chest workout. Now if you have any other questions on this workout or any of the workouts, you could reach me on my body space, my Twitter or on my Facebook page. And for more programs and tips like this from me, you should have come back to bodybuilding.com.

Next, lower yourself downward until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale. Now breathe out on press your upper body back up to the starting position while squeezing your chest. After a brief pause at the top contracted position, you can begin to lower yourself downward again for as many repetitions as needed.

My name is Rachel Flint. I am a captain in the International Guard and winner of 2012 Military Transformation Challenge for bodybuilding.com. I was never athletic in high school, middle school. I just went to class and hung out with my friends and really had no desire to be athletic because I thought it was beyond the realm of possibility for me. It didn't even occur to me that I could be athletic. When I decided to join the military is when I knew that if I was going to survive, they were training. I was going to have to get fit. At that point I was a smoker and so I gave that up and started running. When I was about 23, I went on deployment to Saudi Arabia and was there for about four months. There was somebody over there that showed me the basics of weight training. It was very beginner level stuff. I just built on that and at that point I didn't really do much with it. My natural shape is a pair. I was always very small, had very narrow shoulders and bigger hips. I thought, okay, well if I get fit then I'll probably just be a smaller version of that. I was probably about 140 pounds and I'm 5.7. I'm some of my body fat was in the low 20s which is still healthy but it wasn't something I was comfortable with and so I decided to try to build some muscle and reduce my body fat and see what was underneath. As I started lifting weights and really challenging myself from the gym I started to see that shape change. I was astonished at what I looked like. It's been incredible to see I'm not genetically determined to always have the same body shape. It's incredible. It really can change your whole body. I'm now staying at home, other than my one week in the month in the International Guard. I'm busy with two little girls, I just four and one and a half. I want to set a good example for them and healthy eating is really part of our everyday lifestyle. I got to a point where I knew I just had gotten kind of complacent with my workouts and was ready to kick it up a notch. I've always worked really well with deadlines, this challenge gave me an excellent opportunity to have a 12 week goal and just really hit it hard for those 12 weeks to make the most of it that I could. I used the machines when I very first started because I wasn't real sure about my form and I made the machines took away that guess for me. I think at this point I've gotten through a lot of the trial and error and I know what works well for my body. I'll lift heavy for a while to see how far I could get with that and then I'll switch over to lighter weights with more reps for a while and do that to see what my results are with that. So I tried to always change things that keep an interesting. I do prefer the traditional body building movements. I work out at the same gym every day and the same equipment is there every day so there's now to be some repetition there but whenever I'm working in particular body part I'll change up the exercise to target that particular body part after a while. I work out six days and so I lift weights on all six of those days that I do a five day split and then usually hit my twice in one week usually on on two days or and Thursdays or two days in Fridays. I make sure to give myself a couple days of break between when I hit legs again. I like to do back and my steps together and chest and tie steps together and then shoulders and abs on their own. I tied two cardio two or three times a week. If I have time, if I finish it work out early I'll use the rest of that time to do some cardio. The rest day for me is starts off with church because it's on Sunday so I've got church with my family and we go out to eat and it's a nice day. We'll go to the park and still try to do something slightly active but I really try to just do as little as possible on that day to get me ready for the coming. I take progress pictures every two to three weeks and compare them side by side with previous weeks and not really helps. Set up in a power rack with a bar on the pins. The pin should be set to the desired point, just below the knees, just above or in mid-thigh position. Position yourself against the bar in proper deadlifting position. Your feet should be under your hips, your grip shoulder width, back arched, and hips back to engage the hamstrings. Since the weight is typically heavy, you may use a mixed grip or a hook grip or use straps to aid holding the weight. With your head looking forward, extend through the hips and knees, pulling the weight up and back until lock out. Be sure to pull your shoulders back as you complete the movement. Return the weight to the pins and repeat.

Line your back on a mat with your knees bent and your hands to your side. Lift your legs and bend your knees to 90 degrees. This will be your starting position. Now pull your knees in toward your chest and hold as you exhale. Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position as you inhale. Remember, don't use momentum to swing your legs up. And it keep the motion controlled by your abdominals.

Lion and incline bench with your chest and stomach pressed against the incline. Have dumbbells in each hand with the palms of your hands facing each other. Extend your arms in front of you so they are perpendicular to the angle of the bench. Your legs should be stationary while applying pressure with the balls of your feet. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and raise the weights away from each other and to the sides while keeping a slight bend in your elbow. Try to squeeze your shoulder blades together to get the most effect from the sexier size. Your arms should raise until they are parallel to the floor. Once you've reached the top contracted position hold for a brief moment, then exhale and slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position.

Hey, buddybuilding.com. This is Rich Frowning, two-time CrossFit Games Champion, BSN Athlete, Rogue Fitness Athlete, and we're here at Rogue Fitness Headquarters, about show you guys a workout. Alright guys, the workout today we're going to do is 15-12-9-6-3 of shoulder to overhead pull-ups and 30 double-unders in between each set. So the 15-12-9-6-3 you're actually going to do 15 shoulder to overhead and 15 pull-ups. Then you're going to do your double-unders and 12-12-12-12-9-9 all the way down to the free. Now before we do the workout I'm going to bring Ben in and we're going to show you actually how to do the movements and then also how to scale the movements. If you're not, you can't do the exact weight we've described or the exact movement, we'll show you a few different options to do this workout. Alright, so the first movement we're going to show you is the shoulder to overhead. There's a few different variations you can actually do with this. You can just shoulder press, push press or push jerk. So I'm going to show you all three options. Push jerk, you're going to use, it's probably going to be the most efficient, especially when it gets heavier. You're going to use the most muscular jerk. You can start with the bar on the ground or you can start with it in the rack. You kind of up to you. What Ben's going to do is his feet are going to be right underneath his hips. Hands just outside the shoulders. So he's going to, for this, he's going to act like he's taking it from the ground. He's actually going to clean it up, making sure he's got a good flat back. The bar is actually going to rest here on his shoulders. We want this bar to go straight up and down as possible. The whole time Ben is doing this movement. We're going to start with the shoulder press with the shoulder press. So now we're going to add just a little bit of velocity. You start getting tired out. You want to save your shoulders a little bit, use the legs. He's going to just quick little dip of his knees. With a barbell in front of you on the ground, reach down and grab it with a shoulder width over hand grip. Now stand with the barbell. This will be your starting position. Keep your head up in your back straight and begin to lower the barbell by pushing your hips back as far as you possibly can. Your hamstrings should feel very tight as you do so. Lower the bar slowly to a point just below the knees. Your chin should be up, your butt should be back and your chin should be vertical. The knees should be only slightly bent. After a brief pause, drive through your heels as you return to the starting position.

Lime the floor and place your feet under something that won't move. Your legs should bend at the knees. Elevate your upper body so it creates a V shape with your thighs. Your arms should be fully extended in front of you and perpendicular to your torso with your hands clasped. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and twist your torso to the right until your arms are parallel to the floor. Hold the contracted position for a moment. Then exhale and rotate back to the starting position. Hey guys, I'm Samantha Ann Lee, Bodybuilding.com and Fitment Sponsored Athlete. And today I'm here to take you through my shoulder workout. So today's workout I structured it in the hypertrophy rep range. So we're going to be building those shoulders, making sure that we're rounding them out, hitting all angles of the dealt, front, middle, and back. We're also going to involve some bodyweight movements so that we keep your heart rate up through the whole workout. Today's workout has nine exercises and they're all grouped into three different triceps. Each tricep is composed of three different exercises and you're going to perform all three exercises with little to no rest before repeating that. And then you'll repeat each tricep for times each. For this workout we're going to be using a one to three tempo, meaning on the way up for every exercise you'll be doing one second and then you'll slow it down on the way down for three seconds each. This will really recruit all of the different types of muscle fibers and make sure that you're getting the best workout possible. Alright, let's get started. For the first tricep we're going to start with machine root out flies and then go right into upright rows and then handstand pushups. We're going to be starting with root out flies and the reps are going to be eight to twelve. These you want to select a weight that you'll be failing in that rep range and that you can really keep that tempo going the entire time. Because of the tempo you might have to select a lower weight but that's okay you'll still get a great workout. As you do this movement really focus on keeping your back tight and keeping the weight in your rear delts. Don't let it transfer into your traps. You can do this by making sure that you keep your elbows up through the movement and keep your hands at the same level as your shoulders. Moving to the second exercise of this tricep we're going to be doing upright rows keeping our reps between twelve to fifteen. With these your hand placement should be shoulder with the part and as you bring the bar up keep it close to your body and make sure to drive your elbows through at the end. And make sure keeping with the tempo we're taking three seconds on the way down. With this exercise we're really focusing on the mid-down. We're going to finish up this tricep with handstand pushups doing ten reps or until failure. For this exercise you'll just find a wall or somewhere that you can perform the handstand, place your hands a little bit wider than shoulder with a part and kick your legs up to the wall and then you can perform the regular push-up style only instead of targeting your chest we're targeting your shoulders because we're going up and down. If you're unable to do an unassisted handstand push-up I've also provided a breakdown of how to do an assisted push-up in the article below. So after you're finished with that first tricep take 30 to 45 seconds to rest and then repeat it three times. For our second tricep we'll be doing face pulls, side raises and walking planks. Face pulls will be doing eight to twelve reps and you want to set the cable machine to shoulder height. I get asked a lot where these should be pulling. You want to be keeping your elbows high and pulling them towards your face so that you keep the weight in your rear delts. The second exercise of this tricep is side raises. With these you want to make sure that you choose a weight that you can keep that one to three tempo that we talked about. So you'll probably have to drop the weight from what you're used to. We're going to be doing twelve to fifteen reps. With these you'll start with the dumbbells by your sides, bring them up to shoulder height, squeeze for a second and then take three seconds on the way down. This exercise targets our mid-dults. For the last exercise in this tricep we're going to be doing walking planks for twenty reps. For this exercise you'll start in a plank position. You may want to put more space between your feet. The larger the space between your feet, the easier the movement is and the closer your feet are together, the harder the movement becomes. With this exercise make sure to keep your butt down and your core tight and try not to rock from side to side as you perform the movement. This exercise may look easy but it's really hard because you're keeping tension in your shoulders the whole time and it will really cause your muscles to burn out. For a third tricep we're going to be doing shoulder press, front raises and shoulder taps. For the shoulder press we're going to be doing eight to twelve reps. Again you may have to drop the weight because it's at the end of the workout and we're going to keep with that one to three tempo. As you do this movement you'll want to angle your wrists in a little bit, almost like you're dumping out a cup of water onto your shoulders and then as you go up stop right before you're locked out and then bring it back down. Angling your wrists in and stopping before you lock out makes it to where you don't get a rest at the top and you're keeping the tension in your shoulders. For the front raises we're going to be doing twelve to fifteen reps. You'll start with the dumbbells in front of your legs and bring them up to the 90 degree angle with a slight bend in your elbows. For this workout I am doing both of the front raises at the same time but if you prefer you can do alternating. By this time in the workout keeping that one to three tempo might be really tough because your shoulders should be burnt out. But just keep pushing through. We're almost done and you can rest after the last try set. The last exercise in this try set is shoulder taps and we're going to do twenty to thirty reps. You'll start in the plank position again with your feet either wider to make it easier or closer to make it harder. Again you want to make sure your butt stays down and your core stays tight to ensure that you're not rocking from side to side as you do the movement. Once in the plank position you'll lift one hand to the opposite shoulder and then repeat on the other side. I would recommend if you feel like your shoulders are lagging and incorporate this workout twice a week. Otherwise just incorporate it on your shoulder day once a week. Every one I'm Sean Sarantos. I'm here with ViBold.com. A little bit about myself. I'm an active student member in United States Air Force. I do physical therapy and occupational therapy. I was chosen to be part of the Lift Life at Campaign with ViBold.com, which led me to be part of the team ViBold.com. I'm also the first ever male fitness model sponsored by Sidersports. Today I'm going to be talking to you about some physical and mental road blocks that I personally had to overcome. And hopefully they can help you overcome anything that you're going through in your life. I'm also going to be talking about my nutrition, my training program, and any kind of supplements that I use that you might be interested in. Well, anytime that you deal with an injury physically, you're going to have that mental state that goes back into the rehab, getting back to being functional the way that you used to be. Basically, you have to have that mindset of am I going to let a break me down or am I going to be strong or fort? After that injury coming into the gym is more of a word I go from here for a thing. For me, when I was stabbed, it took away all functioning the wrists. Almost 90% of my functioning the wrists for any kind of exercise. It took away any kind of functions in the chest for a good month and a half also. So for me coming in the gym, I can't do legs every single day as much as I would love to do that and everyone else loves to do legs every single day. Now I have to test everything out. See if it hurts, see if it doesn't hurt. What can I go all out in? What do I have to go happen into? I had to go at different angles on weights and basically, just start from scratch is what I had to do. It was frustrating but exciting at the same time because people would ask me what I'm doing and it gave me a chance to try to explain exactly what I was feeling, what I was going through and how I was helping me out. The three biggest things to overcome, probably the acceptance of how I'm injured, I'm not going to be able to do things I used to. The second thing is coming back into the gym, taking that step and saying, I don't know exactly what I can do but I'm not going to let it slow me down. I'm going to go ahead and do the best I can with what I can do. And the third part is, where am I going to grow from this? Maybe I'm not going to be able to be 100% ever again. How is that going to affect me? You really, really have to take a step back, look at you surroundings and not be shy to ask for help to ask questions because some people might know stuff, they might have gone through what you're going through now. So now that you've learned how I dealt with overcome certain roadblocks, mental and physically, let's go ahead and get into my training program and what helps me out. For me, I trained for at least five days, up to seven days. I don't have a split anymore. I try to write it down and exercise on a certain day but you know what, if I'm feeling squirrely and I want to do arms that day and then by God, I'm going to do arms. I have a set schedule of workouts. I know exactly what I'm going to lift. I write it out. The day I do it on is never up to me. I just go ahead and go in there and whatever my body says, I will break it into two most groups of day. So say I do Monday as chest norms, chest biceps, chest or triceps does matter. Two days I'll go ahead and do back and opposite one so my sets are tri-sips. Leg down Wednesday and Thursday and Friday right back to the Monday. Two days schedule, I think it works best for me to go ahead and get all the as much power and strength that I can get in the beginning of the week when I'm fresh. That's my big movement. That's what I try to do. Later in the week I'll go ahead and do those isolation movements. Try to get those cuts that people like to get. Try to get that muscle endurance is what I try to work on. Plus it gives me whatever back burner energy that I have to go ahead and do the cardio and the high intensity training that I do. Carrier for me I used to run marathon to do tri-athlons but I would burn so much. Sit on a military press bench. Your grip should be wider than shoulder width. Once you've picked up the barbell, lift the bar overhead with your arms straight. Hold the bar slightly in front of your head. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and slowly lower the bar down to shoulder height. Then exhale and press the bar back up to the starting position.

Sit on a military press bench. Your grip should be wider than shoulder width. Once you've picked up the barbell, lift the bar overhead with your arm straight. Hold the bar slightly in front of your head. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and slowly lower the bar down to shoulder height. Then exhale and press the bar back up to the starting position.

Place two dumbbells in front of a flat bench. Sit on the end of the bench with your legs together and the dumbbells behind your calves. The palms of your hands should be facing each other as you pick the dumbbells up. This will be your starting position. Now keeping your torso stationary and forward, exhale and lift the dumbbells straight to your sides until both arms are parallel to the floor. After a brief moment at the top contracted position, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

To get into the starting position, first sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided. Make sure your knees are slightly bent and not long. Next, lean over while keeping the natural alignment of your back and grasp the handles. With your upper arms extended, pull back until your torso is at a 90 degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should feel a nice stretch on your lats as you hold the weight in front of you. This is the starting position. While keeping your torso stationary, pull the handles back toward your torso while keeping your arms close to your body. Pull the handles to your abdominals and make sure to breathe out as you perform the movement. At this point, you should be squeezing your shoulder blades back. Hold the contraction for a second and slowly bring the handles back to the original position while breathing in.

Let's go ahead and dive into the muscular anatomy of your shoulders. One of the best ways to understand this is to think of peeling an onion. On the outer most layer of your onion, you have what are called your deltoids. And these are the big shoulder muscles that most people are interested in building in the gym. So I am going to use a gym here, and just to give you guys an idea, you have got three heads to your deltoids. You have an anterior head, a middle head, and a posterior head. So the anterior head runs from your clavicle or your collarbone, comes down, and a cross, and ends up on your humerus or your arm bone. So it starts at the top or front of your clavicle comes down and a cross. The second is what is called your middle deltoid. So I am going to have a gym just to give you a little quarter turn here. And if you can imagine, this actually runs from the top of your scapula, or your acromion process of your scapula, comes down, and it also attaches on the outer portion of your arm. Last but not least, you have what is called your posterior deltoid. And I will show this on gynsopsit side here. But if you can imagine on the backside of her scapula, it is a scapula spine or that ridge on your shoulder blade, that is where your posterior deltoids start. And it comes down and across, and it also ends up on your humerus or upper arm bone. Now that we have covered your deltoids, I want you to imagine having that on you, right? The deltoids are the outside portion of your on you. And if you peel away that top layer underneath, you are left with a deep layer. And that is what is essentially called your rotator cuff, or your rotary cuff if you are from Indiana like I am. When you are talking about your rotator cuff, there are four muscles that I want you guys to envision. It is going to be kind of hard to see on gym because they are deep to your deltoids, but I am going to point them out to you anyways. The rotator cuff is comprised of your infraspinatus, right? And that is a big muscle that spans the outside portion of your scapula. Underneath your infraspinatus, you have a smaller muscle called your terries minor. The next muscle we are going to talk about is called your superspinatus. And it runs from the top of your scapula, comes down, and it attaches to the inside of your humerus or your arm bone. Last but not least, if you can imagine looking straight through gym and seeing the front side of your shoulder blade, you have got another big muscle there called your sub scapula errors. Now that you have a better understanding of the actual muscles, let's take a look at the bones and joints involved in creating those movements around your shoulder. And if you can imagine they essentially start at the base of your neck, come down, and they end about the top of your lower back. So you've got 12 vertebrae here, and while you may not think they're important, those vertebrae attached to ribs, and then you have your scapula, or your shoulder blade, which rests on top of that thoracic spine. So if you can imagine you've got your scapula right here, and it just kind of rests on the top of your thoracic spine. Last but not least, you have your humerus, or your arm bone. And if you can imagine, your humerus is this long upper arm bone. Now, when you're starting to create actual movements, you're scapula, and your humerus work together to create motion. And as you can imagine, there's a ton of freedom of movement. Your shoulder, like your hip, is a ball and socket joint. So they kind of move into each other like so, and then from that position, you've got tons of freedom of movement. You can flex your shoulder, or raise it overhead. You can extend it, bringing it back down towards your side. You can abduct it, or lift it away from your body. You can abduct it, or add to your body by bringing it closer to the midline. And then last but not least, you have external rotation, or opening your arm up, as well as internal rotation. So as you guys can imagine, there's a ton of freedom of movement at your shoulders. Mobility is absolutely critical, but now you guys should have a better understanding of how all those bones and joints work together to create more fluid movement. And as your recall, it starts on the outer portion of your clavicle, comes down, attaches to your humerus, so it spans that glino-humeral or shoulder joint. So when you're in the gym, you're probably used to doing or seeing people do a front raise. So that's where you're really going to bring out your anterior del. It's not just your anterior del, though, it's also the clavicular portion of your pecs. So these two muscles are working together to create shoulder flexion. Now it only makes sense if you got your anterior del and it creates shoulder flexion, your posterior del or the back side of that muscle, it's going to do the opposite. It's going to create shoulder extension. Last but not least, you've got your middle del and it runs from the top of your scapula comes down and it attaches to your humerus. And if you've ever done a side ladder or something like that in the gym, that's where you're going to see that middle del being isolated. Now keep in mind, we've covered some isolated movements, but anytime you take your arms overhead as you would in a seated military or any kind of overhead press, you're going to be using all three of your deltoid heads synergistically to create that movement. Now that we've covered the deltoids, let's take a look at the individual functions of the rotator cuff. So when we're talking about the shoulder, you've got internal rotation and you have external rotation. Now that's not to be confused with if I've been gym's elbow just a little bit here, you can actually pronate and supinate your hand as well without necessarily rotating your shoulder. It's responsible for internally rotating your shoulder or turning it inwards on a long axis. So if you've got your sub-scap internally rotating, you gotta have something on the back side that externally rotates. So I'm going to have Jin spin around here. And if you can imagine on the back side, you've got your infraspinatus and you have your Terry's minor. Now last but not least, if we're talking about ABduction of the shoulder, you remember you've got your super spinatus and it kind of runs along the top of your scapula or your shoulder blade. It's there to AB duct or lift your arm away from your side. And a lot of times if you read the research and I'm a geek, I read research, it'll tell you that super spinatus is responsible for about the first 30 degrees of ABduction. Now we've gotten kind of geeky and we've talked about internal rotation, external rotation, ABduction, that's all fine and dandy. But when we talk about your rotator cuff, arguably the truest role is to create stability throughout your shoulder joint. So if I just had Jin's arm hanging out here and I pull on her arm a little bit, her rotator cuff works almost like a tractor beam. It's pulling her shoulder back into the socket. So you guys think about when you do a dumbbell row or when you do a chin up and you get long through your arm, your rotator cuff is naturally turning on to create stability throughout your shoulder joint. So while you can do all kinds of isolated movements, if your shoulder and your rotator cuff are doing what they're supposed to, it's not going to take a lot of necessary isolated training to get the kind of result that you're looking for. And if for any reason you do have shoulder issues and overhead pressing gives you some shoulder pain, what I would suggest doing is turning your thumbs or your palms towards you, going to a more neutral grip. This is just going to give that rotator cuff a little bit more room to breathe, and it's going to take some stress off the shoulders as well. When you're overhead pressing, don't forget you're literally using all three heads of your deltoids to create the movement. The posterior del, the middle del, and finally the anterior del toy.
