Today's workout we're going to be working on shoulders. However, we're going to be emphasizing a lot on the posterior delts or rear delts. Your shoulders comprise of three heads. Your anterior, which is a front, your lateral, which is the side and your posterior. In my opinion, I feel like a lot of people emphasize so much on their anterior and their medial heads. And they neglect their posterior head. Stracting your posterior delts will help with your overall shoulder development and help prevent injury. Today we're going to be doing four exercises. The first exercise is going to be shoulder double press. The second exercise is going to be bent over side raise. Third exercise is going to be cable face pulls. And the last and fourth exercise is going to be reverse pectac. Today's workout is only going to be tick about 30 minutes. We're sitting about one minute between each set. All right, let's start this workout. Exercise one, we're going to be doing shoulder double press. We're going to start with one warm-up set, four working sets, and one burnout set. For a working set, we're going to be doing eight to twelve reps to failure. Sour of this workout, what I typically do is I get the dumbbells. Put them on my knees. I kick one dumbbell at a time towards my shoulders. Stabilize it. Get the elbow on up and then push up both together. I do this because I want to prevent any injuries and safely get them up to perform this workout. Once I get the dumbbells up over my head, I drop the weights down until I'm about 90 degrees. It brings them straight back up. When I do my burnout set, what I typically do is I go back to my warm-up weight. Then I try to hit pretty much as much as I can to failure. Exercise two, we're going to be doing bent over side raises. Just like exercise one, we're going to be doing one warm-up set, four working sets, and one burnout set. While working sets, we're going to be doing eight to twelve reps. To set up to do the bent over side raise, what I typically do is I sit at the edge of a bench, bend over so my head is down. Try to pop my shoulders out so I'm trying to activate my rear delts. And I do the reverse fly with my fingers up. When I do this, I only go up just as far as I feel my posterior delts contract. I do see it over standing just because I have a lot more control isolating the rear delts. For a third exercise, we're going to be doing cable face pulls. Just like all the other exercises, we're going to be doing one warm-up set, four working sets, and one burnout set. We're going to be increasing the rep range for these working sets to twelve to fifteen. What I like to do is I like to do it on the ground. By doing it on the ground, I'm not activating any of my other muscles, I'm not using my back. I'm just isolating my posterior delts and focusing on the contraction. When I start off this workout, I grab both ends of the rope with an overhand grip. I try to keep my lower back on the floor. I pull both ends of the rope straight to my forehead. And I try to hold it for about one and a half seconds. Let go slowly and repeat the process. The fourth and final exercise is reverse pectech. Just like the other exercises, we're doing one warm set, four working sets, and one burnout set. For working sets, we're going to be doing eight to twelve reps. When you set up your seat on the reverse pectech machine, what you want to do is you want to make sure that your shoulders and your arms are aligned. The only pivot point is going to be at your shoulder. Each person is going to be a little bit different. You want to just make sure that at the top of each rep you're squeezing your posterior delts. For the burnout set, I jump back to my warm up weight and try to hit 15 to 25 or to failure. In general, as far as any workout, I just like to make sure that I try to keep my muscles on their toes. So they never really know what to expect. So if you want to take a little workout, I could probably do maybe once a week focusing on the posterior delts. And then maybe on another part of the week, focus on the anterior medial. The full workout breakdown is on the page below. If you have any questions for me about this workout, you can contact me on my body space, which is J-A-Y-K, or on my Instagram, which is at drugjake. For more free videos and articles like this, come back to Bodybuilding.com. Thank you for watching.

To start hold a dumbbell in each hand and stand up straight, the dumbbells will rest at your sides at arms length while the palms of your hands face you. This will be your starting position. Now maintaining a stationary torso, exhale and lift the dumbbells to your side with a slight bend in your elbow. Your hands should be tilted slightly forward as if pouring a glass of water. Continue to raise the weight until your arms are parallel to the floor. While spurred brief moment at the top, then inhale and slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position.

Line your back in place your feet firmly on the ground. Your legs should be bent at the knees. Place your hands beside your head. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and raise your upper body to create a V shape with your thighs. Once you feel the contraction hold for a brief pause, then inhale and lower your body back slowly to the starting position.

First, set the bar to a height that best matches your height. Once you've selected the correct height and loaded up the bar, step under the bar and place it on the back of your shoulders. Hang on to the bar with both arms at your sides and the palms of your hands facing forward. Unlock the weight and lift it off the rack by simultaneously pushing with your legs and straightening your torso. Position your legs in a shoulder width stance with your toes pointed slightly out. Be sure to keep your head up at all times and maintain the straight back. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and begin to slowly lower the weight by bending your knees while maintaining a straight posture with your head up. Continue to lower down until you form around a 90 degree angle with your upper legs and calves. Be sure to not let your knees pass your toes while lowering the weight. Finally, exhale and raise the bar back to the starting position. Use the balls of your feet to press the weight up while simultaneously straighten your legs as well. When you're finished, lock the bar back on the rack.

Soye protein is actually extracted from soybeans, growing all over the world, and the way that's extracted or fractionated gives you a very high percent protein by weight with a lot of the other things found in soybeans like carbs and fat greatly reduced. In that islet or soy protein concentrate can be used as a protein source to support training especially for vegetarians. Soy protein becomes because it comes from a plant source can be used as a preferred or primary source of protein if you are vegetarian or a vegan who doesn't consume any animal protein sources or any animal foods. Because soy protein is easily digested and absorbed actually better than casing, you can use it as a protein source after intensive training to support recovery and promoting animal response. Soy protein has also been shown to be a very health or heart health promoting protein source because of its unique amino acid makeup and perhaps other ingredients called isopflabones that are found in soy protein. When you're looking at a soy protein look for the percent protein or look at the number of if it's just a protein powder by itself from soy protein the number of grams of the serving and the number of grams of protein you should have around 90% protein from the outchop powder because soy protein is not 100% protein. So the higher the percentage, especially if it's declared the higher the quality of actually getting protein from soy protein. For some people the isopflabones which are like flavonoids that are found in soy protein can be important especially for women that are seeking their effects on bone health and look there for the amount of isopflabones and there are two names for them, daydzing and genistine and that will tell you the amount of the isopflabones preserving if that's an important thing for your soy protein and choice. Protein from soy just like any other protein in amounts more than 20-25 grams may not lead to any additional antibody response muscle after intensive training. So if you consume a soy protein dose more than 20-25 grams, the additional amounts will likely be burned as a fuel or potentially could be going into making fat. The other thing to consider is what to combine it with. As with any other protein you can combine soy protein with anything else you want to, carbs, creatin, branch-chain amino acids, gloomy, anything else even other proteins to stack it up with.

Position yourself into a staggered stance with the rear foot elevated and the front foot forward. Hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in each hand letting them hang to the sides. This will be your starting position. Begin by descending, flexing your knee and hip to lower your body down. Maintain good posture throughout the movement. Keep the front knee in line with the foot as you perform this exercise. At the bottom of the movement drive through the heel to extend the knee and hip to return to the starting position.

To perform this exercise, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the bar is loaded up with your desired weight, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders under it. Now lift the bar from the rack by pushing simultaneously with your legs and straightening your torso. Step away from the rack and position your legs to a shoulder width medium stance with your toes pointed slightly out. Keep your head up at all times and maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and begin slowly lowering the bar. Sit back with your hips as though you were going to sit on a chair. Maintain the arch in your back and keep your head up as you descend. Continue lowering the weight until your hip and knee form a line parallel to the floor. Now exhale and lift the bar back to the starting position leading the movement with your head. Push the floor with the heels of your feet as you use your abductors to push your knees out so they stay in alignment with your feet.

Connect a standard handle to a tower and move the cable to the highest pulley position. With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arms length away from the pulley with the tension of the weight on the cable. Your outstretched arm should be aligned with the cable. With your feet positioned shoulder width apart, reach upward with your other hand and grab the handle with both hands. Your arm should still be fully extended. Now, in one motion, pull the handle down and across your body to your front knee while rotating your torso. Keep your back in arm straight and your core tight while you pivot your back foot behind your knees to get a full range of motion. Maintain your stance and keep your arm straight. Return to the starting position in a slow and controlled manner. Repeat this motion to failure. Then switch sides.

With the pad of the calf raised machine at the appropriate height, place your shoulders under the pads and position your toes facing forward. The balls of your feet should be secured on top of the block with your heels extending off of it, push the lever up by extending your hips and knees until you can stand up straight. The knees should always keep a slight bend and should never be locked. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible while flexing your calves. Ensure that your knees do not move and there should be no bending at all during this movement. Hold the top contracted position for a brief moment, then inhale and slowly lower yourself back to the starting position.

Stand straight up while holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Place the balls of your feet on a sturdy and stable wooden board that is around 2-3 inches tall. You can point your toes in different directions for different emphasis. Your heels should extend off the back of the board and touch the floor. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and raise your heels off the floor by contracting your calves. Hold the top contracted position for a brief moment, then inhale and slowly lower your heels back to the starting position.

Grab a dumbbell in each hand with a slightly less than shoulder width overhand grip. The dumbbell should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended in your back straight. Keep the dumbbells close to your body as you move them up and the elbows should drive the motion. Continue lifting the weights until they nearly touch your chin. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position.

Stand with a loaded barbell in front of you. Grab the barbell with an overhead grip wider than shoulder width. Clean the bar to shoulder height. This will be your starting position. Now press the bar overhead taking care to move your head out of the bar's path. Exhale during this portion of the motion. Then inhale and slowly lower the bar back down to your shoulders.

What's up guys, today we're going to be going over a full shoulder and tricep workout. I'm going to be going over some of the common mistakes you'll see in the roast split. So let's get after it. When it comes to an effective workout, today we're doing shoulders and triceps, you really want to prioritize your weaker underdevelop muscle groups first. A lot of guys when they start their shoulder workouts, they're starting with shoulder presses or overhead presses. Now I get it. The compound movements are going to require the use of more muscle groups. You're going to be able to lift a little bit heavier and have a little bit more mechanical tension. But here's the problem with overhead presses. When you're doing overhead press, your anterior delts are mostly engaged in neglecting your lateral and rear delts. If you really want to work on your underdeveloped muscle groups, for a lot of guys, it is those medial delts and the rear delts. So what we're actually going to do is we're going to flip our sequencing of the exercises. So we're actually going to start with rear delt cable flies. And then we're going to superset that with a lateral race. Here's what everybody gets wrong with the cross cable rear delt fly. They're squeezing their scapula together at the top of the movement. The rear delts are not involved in scapula retraction. Keep the shoulder blades relaxed. Squeezing them together would only be beneficial for targeting the rhomboid, but since the rear delts only insert on the humors and attach on the scapula, shoulder extension and abduction would be what targets the rear delts best. What I want you to do is protract those shoulders, pull apart. And this is where you're ending. Anything further, you're not really isolating the rear delts. You're just getting the rhomboids and maybe a little bit of the traps involved. We're going to drop the cables. You're going to perform four sets until technical failure. After your fourth set with little to no rest in between, you're going to perform a drop set, where you lighten the load anywhere from 10 to 30 percent and proceed again to technical failure. I also want you to notice that I am not using momentum and I am controlling the eccentric portion of the movement. Alright, so now we're going to be moving into an overhead press. The reason why I didn't want to start with an overhead press is because I think you're going to get a much greater stimulus to fatigue ratio during these after you've already pre-exhausted the lateral delts. Slow and controlled reps on the way down, keeping it as close to my face as I can. I'm coming all the way down to the top of my chest, near my clavicle. And then I'm going to hold there for a second and get a nice pause. Push straight up. Again, guys, the goal here is to work until technical failure through a full range of motion, especially the bottom portion of the movement. Oh, doing a lot. Yeah, that's how you work to failure. And no, see, I'm not using a lot of weight, but getting more of a hyper-trophic response stimulus in my muscles by lifting that way. Alright, so now we're going to move on to triceps. I like to do some variation of an overhead extension or a skull crusher. You're going to give the shoulders a little bit of a break because I plan on finishing off this workout with dips. So, let's give this a go. Hold it at the bottom post for a second. Come up. Notice how I'm keeping the bar belt back. So, I'll go in my head, keeping it tension on the tricep. For this particular exercise I am using a straight bar, you can use an easy crow bar or you can use dumbbells. Use whatever piece of equipment you need in order to connect with that movement and that muscle group better. I'm going to do my third and fourth set. I'm going to do two drops at the end, so I'll be doing an 8 to 10 reps with the heavier weight and then I'm going to drop and do anywhere from 15 to 20 reps with a lighter weight. Alright, so we're going to finish this workout off with dips. Now, if I'm fresh, I can probably do easily 20 to 30 dips. When you do them like this, I guarantee you're going to have a hard time doing 10. Here's how we're going to do this. Starting out at the top position, I'm going to slowly lower myself down, slow the control at the eccentric. And I'm going to get as deep as I can. Get a nice deep stretch on those triceps. Press up. One, you have to train legs. You can't skip it. I think that's something I did when I was, when I was younger too, like they, like they as vicious is going to hurt. It's going to leave each, a good leg day to some extent is going to leave you a little bit of pain tomorrow. But you have to train legs. There, there, your largest muscle group. There are also, and this is going to go into the other key thing with trying to build muscle and also build strength. And there are also, because their your largest muscle group and because so many other muscles are just involved from it, an isometric standpoint. And in every single leg motion, there are the muscle group where you're going to lift the heaviest possible weights you can. Your deadlift, regardless of what implement you're using, should be your strongest lift. And the fact that you get to subject your body to that kind of load is going to send the hormonal signals required for you to grow. So my first thing is going to be you have to train legs. And it, not once a week, that's like 52 times a year. It doesn't feel like a lap, but try to get it in twice a week at least. The second key thing I think is just making sure that you build your workout around multi-joint motions. I think you want to look at, I like to divide the body into, or I like to divide motions into five different groups. You've got six different groups actually. I can't count. You've got, you've got an e-dominant move. So that's going to be any kind of squat or lunge. I would put in that category too. You've got a hip dominant move, any kind of hip hinge, and we want to make sure we have that. That's going to be our deadlift. And then we have four families of upper body moves. We've got vertical pull and vertical push. Vertical pull is going to be any kind of pull-up or chin up concept. Vertical push is going to be any sort of overhead concept overhead presses. And then we've got horizontal pull and horizontal push. We want to make sure it's critical for everybody. Before you even touch the vertical pull, vertical push ideas, the first upper body motion you've got to be able to master is the row. The row should be one of your strongest upper body motions. It's going to keep you healthy and it's going to help build your back. That's a really, really large muscle group and it's also a really key muscle group for shoulder health. And then you've got obviously horizontal push. That's the fun one for guys. It's bench presses, push-ups. And I like to, you want to make sure that you cover all of those bases. You want to hit at least every single week. You want to do at least one of those motions. The way I like to break it down and the simplest way I think and the safest way I think over the long term to break things down is to treat this either like a four day or a six day split. Your first day you're going to train legs, get it out of the way. Second day you're going to train all your pulling muscles. That's going to be your horizontal rows, your vertical pull. If you can get, if you're at that point where you can really manage pull ups and you can handle pull downs and your shoulder health is good. And then you can get in a little bit of biceps. Your date three would then be push. Right? And that's going to be, that's going to be driven by your bench presses, your overhead presses. You can get a little bit of triceps in there as well. And then you can repeat that cycle. That's one way to do it. The other way to do it if you only want to train four days a week, if you're a little bit more of a beginner, then we can go lower upper lower upper upper. Right? So my day one is going to be my leg day. I'm going to make sure to cover my hip hinge, my knee dominant move. My day two is going to be my upper body day. I'm going to cover my, I'm going to basically go through a horizontal push motion, a horizontal pull motion. I'll get in a pull up idea. I may get in some kind of shoulder idea. And that's going to be my workout. I could take a day off and then repeat that. There are a lot of different ways to do it. All of them can be effective. I think over the course of your training, over and that's, you know, talking like decades, you should play with all of them and utilize all them because they're going to fit different phases of your life, which I'm sure we'll get into a little bit later. And thinking, okay, let's keep this around eight to 10 reps. Because that's what I'm going to feel it the most. You don't have to feel it on, you don't have to feel it when you're lifting heavy. You're, you're, you'll feel it the next day. Just get the lift done. And you can kind of focus on the burn a little bit more of the my muscle connection. When you get to some of those accessory ideas later, that doesn't mean your form should be horrible. And you should be arching your back and your butt should be sky high off the bench when you're bench pressing. But it does mean that, you know, it's not necessarily about feeling it fully in your chest. Right. There's going to be a time in a place for low rep, high weight. And then vice versa. So there's going to be a time in a place for your program. No matter what kind of goal you're training for at this point. The, the, just of it is, everybody should be lifting heavy at some point in their program during their week. And then there's a time in a place for your higher rep lower weight accessory work. Yeah. I think it's too about the relationship between muscle and strength. Right. When I am lifting a little bit heavier, when I'm lifting a little bit heavier, I'm going to not only develop muscle, but I'm building strength and I'm building power. And if I can build, if I can enhance my strength and power, if I can, if I can take that to another level, then when I get to those kind of pump exercises or those moments where I'm going to focus on the my muscle connection, I'm going to be able to use a larger load and still hit higher reps, right? So it makes sense to play in a lot of sandboxes in terms of in terms of the, the, the reps game you're using. And in terms of going very, very heavy and challenging yourself. And at the same time, having those moments where we're not going as aggressively. Yeah. Absolutely. What is your number one piece of advice for someone not to do when they're trying to gain muscle? It's funny because I'm almost going to contradict myself. I think it's not what I said you should do. We just talked about lifting heavy and I think that's really, really, really important. But the number one thing not to do when you're trying to build muscle is I think thinking of motions at, like, just lifting almost, like, I think the number one thing not to do is let motions become point A to point B, right? What happens, I think very often, I think this is a, is a, is a flaw or an issue, especially when you're beginner in the gym, is you're, you're going to, okay, I'm going to do a Biceps curl. So I've just got to get the weight up, right? Well, I'm just, I just got to get the weight up. And there is a time in the place for that. And we, you know, that that's kind of the heart of a deadlift. We want to get the weight up with proper mechanics. And we've got to learn those mechanics first. And we've got to understand the muscles we were engaging first. I think not enough people take the time to understand the muscles that they're supposed to be using. And none of people take the time to understand, you know, a deadlift is, yes, fundamentally it is, I'm just picking a weight up off the ground. But it's mainly driven by my hamstrings and my glutes. And I need to understand that those muscles are working, I need to be able to feel it in those muscles. I've got to master that before I start lifting crazy heavy. Yeah, absolutely. So, so a little bit of what we're going into in a little bit is I'm developing that mind muscle awareness and just overall that body awareness. So, something we always hear people say is I'm trying to build muscle. Should I do cardio? Well, yeah, she should do cardio, right? We need to keep our heart healthy, right? But how do we keep it at bay in the sense that we're not going to affect muscle mass when our primary goal is building muscle? Cardio, I think, is Cardio is very, very underrated from a strength perspective. I think people tend to, I am a very big believer overall in making sure that you don't, I think when we get too caught up in one modality and we forget everything else, we're short-circending the gains that we may be trying to make in that in that one area. And I think that's what tends to happen with cardio because if we can make our heart stronger, if our heart can more effectively plump blood throughout our system, right? Then when I go to, when I go to sit down to the bench press or to any of my strength exercises, I'm going to have a little bit more in me to get another couple reps on top, which provides more muscle building stimulus in the end. So I think we should all have a cardio component in our workout. How we piece that together is sort of the riddle and I think there are a couple ways to do it because you also don't want to, you don't want to say go through like an hour long strength workout and then sit on a treadmill for an hour or do something like that because then you're just wearing yourself out, you're not giving yourself a chance to recover. I think there are a couple of things that people can do. One, there's, there's a lot of increasing research on zone two, right? Zone two cardio, just the idea of being 50 to 60% of your heart rate and living in that area and how that can help build your engine. And that is also a little, that's also not necessarily body taxing cardio. I would contend with zone two too, a lot of the reason the research is coming out and a lot of the reason we need it more is because humans are moving a lot less than they used to and zone two is literally me walking my dog or me going to the grocery store except I don't go to my grocery store anymore because I just ordered for man's on it. So we can get that zone two in and I think if you can make time for an hour of that a day, there's nothing wrong with that. And hour of taking a walk, there's no harm, right? The more active we can be the better. I think that all this sort of counts as as very base level cardio. I also think there's value and kind of in revving your engine up a lot more. When I sit down to a really, really hard set of like six reps on the deadlift, my heart rate will wind up pretty high. Especially if I'm doing three to four sets of that. So there's no harm in training that level of cardio and getting in like you know, eight ten minutes of hit on the back end of your of your strength workout or as a stand alone workout if you have that kind of time. So I think it's just it's making sure that we're smart about our cardio but I think it needs to be a part of your training. I would probably limit it if I'm going to do like a hit style session or some kind of interval session on a rower to twice a week because I don't want to kill myself and then try to but try to get in that other zone two cardio as often as I can because it's just gonna help. the weight winds up moving upwards so that's the concentric contraction there's a lot of other little pieces that go into it too and that in order for me to get that really clean biceps contraction I have to have tightness throughout the rest of my body I've got to make sure shoulders my shoulder blades are tight my abs are tight my glues are tight and that allows me to really get the most out of the concentric contraction that's what everybody knows we all squeeze we all can curl something up and squeeze our biceps that's the concentric the eccentric contraction occurs when basically we're lowering the weight but we're not passively lowering the weight so we're still applying a level of force we're just letting the force of gravity on whatever load we're lifting exceed the force that exceed the force that we might be applying that's kind of a standard concentration contraction and it shouldn't the thing people miss about the concentric or I said concentric I'm an eccentric wow second pause at the top very briefly one second and then try to lower make sure that lower takes two to three seconds that's going to ensure that my biceps have to eccentricly contract because if I just if I just all of a sudden stop contracting my biceps at the top of the curl the weight's going to fall that's one not really good for my joints and it's a mechanism for injury and too I'm leaving a lot of gains both in the short term and in the long term on the table because I haven't appreciated the time on the retention those two extra seconds of work that I'm going to get with that Backhaff will be focused on more mental and emotional health. Really great conversation, Q, up for you guys. Let's get into it. We are going to start off with time-under tension as our first topic. Gabe defined the practice of time-under tension, the use cases and the benefits, and why this pertains to every level and not just beginners. Just high-levelics plan. The definition is create, so everybody's only no tension. How we create that tension, whether it is through a large heavy load, a moderate load, a small load, that is the first choice. How are we going to create the resistance? Now it's up to us as to how much time we can put under the concentric and eccentric phases. A lot of times you see beginners on a bench press, maybe you have the first thing that you see where they're just trying to bang it out as many reps as possible. Very rarely actually hitting their full ranges of motion. Not understanding how their scapula is working on, not understanding that they actually need to lock their elbows out. Trying to get as much done as possible. It actually has quickly as possible when you could create more tension being as our bodies a lever pulley system. You don't need to just lift up one large crate. You can hold one large crate or even one smaller crate and create more time in that lever pulley system to create more adaptation to tear more muscle fibers. Also to confuse the central nervous system so that your body doesn't just get used to banging out as many reps as possible. In terms of how a beginner should approach, I always start with time to centrics. If we're doing a bench press, three seconds to get to your chest explode off fast on the concentric on the shortening phase. You can do the time to centrics and you can do time to pause it. It's a down quick hold at 90 degree level, press back up from there. Just finding ways to increase as much tension as possible rather than trying to add as much load as possible. I found in terms of sustainability is most beneficial for joints for ligaments for tendons and then also just to not burn out your CNS because me as a college athlete, we had our test which the one was 225 pound bench press as many times as you could do it. You can get under it and do it like 39 times with this sloppy form. Create a lot of tension because you're using a lot of weight and you're doing it fast or you could take that 200 or 25 pounds and do it as slow as a rep on the eccentric phase on the stretch and as slow as a rep on the eccentric phase because all that tissue actually knows is strain and then that strain is what's going to cause that temptation. So it is, I'm going to say it's lazy because you know good old fashion have you lifting definitely works but if you're constantly stuck in that facet and you're not finding any progress that's where then for the higher level athlete you know I want to know what their program is looking like and if they're just trying to bang out as many reps as possible you know I challenge them unlike why don't you hold a pause at the bottom you know find where your strength is at at your end range of motion rather than you know your shortest phase and I think that's where a lot of people kind of sell themselves short is you know whether it's you know the push ups whether it's you know even like bicep curls guys that are kind of just going you know from 90 up like you have this full lovely So we're talking squat deadlift and bench. Let's break that down. Yeah, I mean, breath is like vital for lifting. I think I teach breathing so much for my clients. It's insane. I like to break down by three breaths. You have your Valsava maneuver. You have your dynamic breath actually four breaths. So Valsava dynamic foundational and diaphragmatic. So diaphragmatic is more of that relaxation breath. Your Valsava will be more for your one rep max and that counting into your brace. Your dynamic is when you're breathing in going down and breathing out as you come up and foundationals when you're breathing out throughout the entire thing. Each of those have different goals for the performance. When it comes to squatting, delifting and benching, I typically stay within the foundational Valsava and dynamic breaths. The dynamic is the easiest one for people to understand. That is when you take a breath at the top. Maybe you're taking a breath as you're going so you're going down into the squat and then you're exhaling as you come up. And what's happening here is you're getting that core contraction through the concentric movement of the exercise. So as you're pushing up into that squat, you're going to be getting more activation of your pelvic floor, your core and your diaphragm. This really plays into how do you properly brace. So are you breathing 360 degrees around? And this isn't just for Valsava. You should be treating your warmups, the same way that you treat your one rep max. So you should be taking that nice deep breath in. You should be expanding 360 degrees around. So you're not putting too much pressure into your abdominal wall or into your pelvic floor. You're distributing it like a can. So when you step on a closed can, you can stand on it. It's nice and solid. If you break that seal, you stand on it. You crush the can. So number one, take us back to a time in your life where becoming a collegiate athlete became a very real possibility. Was there pressure to make that happen or did the seem like the pinnacle of what you had been dreaming about growing up? Yeah, it is not talked about enough. So I'm really grateful that I have the opportunity to talk about it today. I would say it was a little bit of both. It was something that I knew I wanted to do from a very young age. That being said, I, for some reason, put pressure on myself at a very young age to reach this goal. There are actually two concepts and psychology that I think about for some reason I developed around 12 and one is called the audience effect, which is essentially when you think when you start to realize as a human being that other people might be observing what you do and so you sort of tweak your behavior based off of that. And as a tennis player, I don't know if I said that, I fully tennis. In growing off an in college, I became very self-aware of my performance. And my results and if people saw that I was winning. So I wanted to win and I wanted to do well, but I also wanted, you know, my coach to see me and I wanted my parents to see me and I wanted my friends and colleges. So that that audience effect, I developed that like maybe 12. And then there's a second concept called the spotlight effect, which is sort of similar. It's when you think everybody is watching you more than they are really. And again, at a young age, I just figured I had all of these eyes on me. Even though I probably didn't have as many as I thought. And I started developing this mindset of achieving goals that weren't necessarily for myself. But they were for how it looked on paper, how it looked with a ranking, or, you know, a social status, or to get to a certain, you know, college conference. So that pressure I definitely started putting on myself. And it was emphasized when I was injured. My crucial years of college recruiting. I had this shoulder injury that I couldn't figure out. And it really put me in this mindset of scarcity. You know, I was never good enough. I was afraid. I wouldn't get to where I wanted to be. All of my friends were being recruited and signing and it was end of my junior year. And I couldn't hit a forehand because I felt constant pain in my shoulder. And so I sort of developed this mindset from like age 12 to 16. I mean, of feeling like everybody was watching me of not having intrinsic goals, but having goals based off of external outcomes and a feeling scared that I wouldn't ever be good enough. And so, you know, it's kind of a loaded answer. But it just goes to show that a lot of this, like, a lot of the mental health stuff that I dealt with later in life, started developing at a young age. And how do you think that impacted the years to follow and even today too? You're a little bit of that fishbowl effect as some may call it as well. And just the overall pressure is that maybe you just put on yourself. Even if you weren't necessarily getting this from a parent, a coach, you know, college recruiters, etc. Yeah, it completely translates. very powerful way so that's the first bullet point the second one is that I think high level athletes do this very well and I encourage everybody to think about this in their daily life is where you are putting your energy our energy is our most valuable currency it is the most valuable thing we have that we can control and what we give our energy to is like what we give our life to and when you start to really understand what that means you start to see where in your life you're giving energy to things that maybe aren't serving you and so I think that elite athletes are really careful with where they're putting their energy nothing moves without energy right so you're in control of it but you have to direct your attention and your awareness in a way where you're you're expanding that energy to get something valuable back and then the third thing I would say sort of what I touched on in your last question which is just having a purpose that goes beyond yourself so I think as athletes especially tennis players we are very selfish I when I was growing up it was my schedule it was my tournaments it was what I wanted you know where I needed to be on the weekends do I have my towel and my water and my shoes and my rackets like it was so selfish and self-centered and the most elite athletes that I have worked with and that I've observed have this purpose that goes beyond themselves and if they didn't have it earlier in their career then maybe they developed later in their career and you can see that transition that change like if you agacies a great example earlier in his career a little bit of a head case you know all he wanted to be was number one in the world and then it gets to that spot and it's not fulfilling him and so later in his career he starts giving a lot of his earnings and his money away to charities that he cares about and getting involved and you see not only his performance but his personality elevate and so that last point is something that I encourage everybody whether you think of yourself as an athlete or not you should always be asking yourself what am I doing that is going beyond myself. I love it you know and I think I think people who follow a routine like this and take these things seriously whether they are novice athlete a marathon runner a weekend warrior whatever label you want to put on it I think we throw too much shade at those people because I think we need to reverse the narrative of what we consider normal I think we need to stop looking at blowing through $100 and getting drunk in a bar every weekend as normal and I think we need to start normalizing people really prioritizing their health and wellness I think we've started to see that shift specifically in the last couple of years I'm fine with the people doing their ice baths and the people who are putting sonas in their backyard I will not hear me throwing shade at any of those people I think we need to do a little less of that just kind of get people on the same narrative of what longevity can look like and make that the norm. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. What's up, bodybuilding.com. Miss Neres, my name is Danielle Bitz, and today I'm joined by Rachel Marriotti. Rachel is a licensed mental health therapist here in New York City as well as professional fitness coach. Her main focus in mental health treatment is building habits in order to grow mental resilience while addressing the physical and spiritual side of a person's being. Rachel began her work in a psychoanalytic clinic setting, treating patients with depression and anxiety. While in pursuit of her license, she started her own practice called mental hygiene, which is focused on building habits around mindfulness, emotional awareness, and breaking down negative beliefs through understanding words and reactions. She's been featured in Women's Health as a Mental Health Expert, was hired by Nike to speak on the Mind Body Connection, as well as by Athleta as a Mental Health Advisor for their Women's Online Community. Rachel has her master's degree in applied psychology from NYU and an NCSF certification in personal training. Rachel, welcome to the B become podcast. Thank you, Danielle. For the conversation that we have today. Yeah, I'm looking forward to this conversation. We had a good phone call before this, so I'm looking forward to it. Yeah, absolutely. What are these six pillars, and how did they really affect our daily well being? Let's break those down. Yeah, so to clarify, the six pillars is an assessment tool I use for mental hygiene clients. Not for personal training clients. And really, I'm not telling people what to do with these six pillars. I'm more so gaging their expectations around where they're at. And the six pillars are exercise diet and sleep, are the first three, and then relationships, mental health, and purpose are the latter three. So the first three are really looking at the body, and how a client who's wanting to work on a specific area of their mental health, how they're handling their body. And what their expectations are, and I have them rate each pillar one to ten. So it just gives me, it's really, it gives me a sense. This is done on the first session, and it gives both of us a sense of, okay, actually, didn't realize I could spend more time in my relationships, or I can, I didn't realize how much I wasn't connected with my purpose. So the latter three pillars are really where more sensitive, important conversations come up, the body side of the being is also important, and there's some information in the sleep before losing sleep, usually it's tied to our mental health, what's keeping you up at night. So it's just a gauge of how someone's handling their life. And I guess I never called it six pillars of wellness, but you can consider it that, but I don't strictly label it that. Yeah, it's a really good question. And the first thought that came to my head was that we as human beings, especially given our media structure, we all have a hard time living in ambiguity. And I think it becomes an identity at a certain point, right, especially younger athletes, you know, let's talk about athletes specifically here for a second, even though we've really moved into that, you know, how in athletes mindset transitions into mental durability. If an athlete starts a sport, let's say eight or nine, they're starting early in early these days. I mean, they're combing for scholarships at 11, 12 years old. At this point. So, you know, someone starting to be crazy. Yeah, yes, let's talk about it. You know, they're starting to sport eight and nine. They're getting really, really great at the sport 10, 11, 12. Okay, 13, 14, 15, let's start recruiting. Okay, now I have to be number one because that would be sought out by the one scout that's gonna be coming here to look at thousands of athletes in a weekend. Okay, now I got into college. All right, now I have to work my way into the starting line up. Okay, great. Number one, now I want to be all American, right? Okay, now I want to go pro when I'm done with college. So this starts from such a young age. What happens when it ends? Because it will end and that's what a lot of people, younger people don't realize I didn't realize it at a certain point and became my identity. My sports certainly did. When it ends, they are facing complete mental crisis. I mean, they are experiencing, in, for lack of a better word, and identity crisis. They don't really know who they are without this sport, without the training, without somebody telling them where they have to be and when they have to be there and how much they have to practice for this one thing that they've set their sights on, right? So let's talk about that range, that time span, of where it's such a fixated duration, and then that ends, right? And what happens? So how do they transition in a normal life? Sure, yeah, well, it's something that a lot of people can relate to for sure. You know, spending that much time in a sport, I was in gymnastics at age four, and I really didn't stop sports until I was 18. And for those that are out there following that scenario, more extreme going elite, all American and pro, and then it comes to an end, I think it can end up in a crisis if there are, depending on a lot of things. They called the squad the king of exercises, but it's more than that. It's the first exercise you ever did, and nobody taught you how. You invented it. We all did, even though we didn't know it had a name. Some of us stop squatting as we grow up. Others put immense loads on their backs and squat to break records, or to build superhuman legs. At its best, the motion is the same as when you were a child. You sit down. Then you stand back up. As an exercise, the squat predates bodybuilding, powerlifting, and even Olympic weightlifting. Its roots stretch back into the days when weight training was the domain of professional strongmen who performed incredible feats in front of wide-eyed audiences. You know, I started when I was very young, and I had been around the sport mind-tired life, but I got away from it for a long time, and went into bodybuilding for a while, and I got into powerlifting for a while, and then I came back to weightlifting. I think the reason why I've had success as a coach is because I've had a lot of questions that I've learned a lot over the years. Generally, when you get stronger in the squat, it makes your entire organism stronger. I've proven time and time again that just when you're physically stronger in the squat, everything will increase. Your arms will gain size, your chest will get bigger, your bench press will go up. Everything gets stronger because your organism is an entire whole in a stronger. So in the past, I've researched the history of the actual squat as an exercise, and I went back as far as the modern day Olympics in 1896, and I found that it had actually predated that. So I started looking to old circus performers or old-time strongmen to try to find out how it started. What I found was, you hear names like Arthur Sachsen or Lewis Seer, other strongmen from the past. As I researched further, I found out that it came from a guy, and he referred to it as Professor Lewis Atilla. And one of his students was, again, a Eugene Sandow. He became very popular, not just because of a strengthless because how he looked. And ultimately he became the first bodybuilder, and 19-in-one-e-held a competition for bodybuilding. The reason I bring him up is because he had a book that he wrote in 1894, and it was a physical culture of training. And in one of his exercises, he clearly describes what's known as a squat and used that exercise. And so I believe that Atilla was his coach and taught him how to do it. So I believe that Professor was the guy who actually invented the squat as an exercise. Sandow's worldwide fame for his strength, and just as importantly his physique inspired countless young men and women to follow in his footsteps. But unlike his immense bent presses and other unique lifts, his version of the squat was a light one done with small dumbbells. Took another 30 years for someone to push the upper limits of what could be squatted with a heavy barbell. The reason was simple. How would they get it on their back? The way that they would squat in the past, there was no apparatus. You know, there was no bracket. And all the barbells back then were shot loaded, which means that it was a globe type barbell that was a fixed diameter and a fixed size. And to make it heavier, they were just poor shot inside the globe. So they were able to take that barbell and just stand it up on its long end and then grab the barbell and tilt it and catch it on their back and then do a squat. And then set it back now on those how they squat it back then. Same way when they did a one arm bent press, they would load around their shoulder, lean to one side and press. In the 1920s, Henry Steinborn earned a name for himself by squatting more than 500 pounds for five reps with a barbell that he tipped over onto his back. With triumphs like his and the increasing popularity of squatting for training in the Olympic lifts of the snatch and clean and jerk, the stage was set for the squat to take its place among the great exercises. So let me guys back then, we're more interested in just becoming bad asses. Like, what can I do to challenge myself? It was a different mindset. They weren't doing it because they wanted to look a certain way. They're doing it because they just wanted to be strong. So they would see how much can I put over my head with one hand, how much can I do with two hands anyhow? In the sport of weightlifting, was revived in 1896 with the modern Olympics and they had the one hand and the two hand lift. And after that, you still have the strong man and the circus performers doing everything. But as the Olympic movements gain traction, more people start training with weights. They wanted to compete at that high level and they became having world championships again. And so when people are doing snatch and clean and jerk, they found that they would start doing squats as a system exercises into it evolved to where you had in the 1950s. Well, and guys like Paul Anderson, you can show it up. Anderson, a gold medal winning Olympic lifter in strong man, popularized the Barbell squat as a stand alone lift by putting up unheard of numbers. His personal best squat was a monstrous 1200 pounds. His best official squat was 930 pounds in 1965. He trained relentlessly squatting tractor wheels and 55 gallon drums from a hole in the ground. His accomplishments made him a celebrity whose name was synonymous with strength. That's pretty much how it started to change because, you know, people saw how powerful he was and people like him from being immense squatters. And that's pretty much what change when people saw how much core strength they had. You know, they started becoming more mainstream people want to look like these guys. Not was available through mail order, they could order your barbells and plates and racks and things started to spread. And this is how it started to transition. People started to become more aware of what they're doing. This is how things started to build where people could grow is because the information was now available and so was equipment. And just like now here in the modern day where the internet is so accessible, you can get anything you want very quickly. So when the magazines and back then to that era was what helped spread the word and people could start to see how it was growing. By the 1960s, squatting had become mainstream. People could order racks and barbells through the mail and read and magazines about how to squat to increase strength and build better physics. But in the 1970s, a new generation of bodybuilders and power lifters redefined what was possible by using the squat for leg development. So really the first person that I saw that had just a straight freaky squat was Tom Plats. So Tom Plats in Franco Colombo were really the two people that I actually watched or read about to really had good squats that were strong and also could do for reps. So that comes from mostly gold narrow bodybuilders. So that's really early on in my career who I kind of looked to from a squat standpoint. Tom Plats was a guy that when I first saw his legs when I was a kid, I was just, I was blown away. The changes of game for me like that was one of the things that was wrong-pressive. And but to see in his physique and his legs, I managed to glue my mind. Athletes like Plats, Anderson, Steinborn and Sandow showed the world the possibilities of the human body. They made squatting look easy even under weights that should have broken them. Together they helped cement what has become one of the cardinal rules of strength training. If you want to be big and strong, you need to get under the barbell and squat.

I do want to help educate our user before we jump into things a little more granularly. What is contrast therapy? And where does that come into play in pairing with heat? Yeah, for sure. So when it comes to contrast therapy, we're looking at deliberate heat exposure in deliberate cold exposure. So you're basically going from a very hot environment to a very cold environment. For most people right now, it's either they're hitting a hot tub and in for insana, traditional sauna steam room, and then either doing a cold shower or they're doing a cold plunge. And there's different effects to that that essentially create a bodily high for people, and it becomes very addicting for some people too. But contrast therapy in its essence is starting to create to me probably the more significant psychological responses that we're looking for for people, and it's actually helping decrease depression. And when you when you separate the two though, like cold exposure and sauna therapy in itself without pairing, there's tons of benefit. But when you combine the two, all of a sudden you're looking at this cocktail of effects to where it's almost starting to also point toward longevity benefit. There hasn't been enough research done on contrast therapy for us to be able to say like this is the exact specific protocol for longevity, but there is stuff specifically pointing toward depression and being able to cure that. And if there's one thing obviously right now in the United States is that there's a lot of people that are anxious, having anxiety, have depression, and are looking for ways to be able to cope with it that are healthy that don't have consequence. And contrast can be a great form for that. I think it's a really great way to slow down my history of contrast therapy. I was first introduced to it back in my collegiate athlete days, but that was more so from a physical recovery standpoint. It was, hey, we have a double header tomorrow. We need to do recovery remosals as quickly as possible. Go hot cold, hot cold, hot cold, right? There was no discussion about the mental aspects of it. Now you'll feel it. Now anybody out there who has done it or if you haven't done it, you know, proceed with caution when you're trying anything new, just do a couple rounds to start. Don't go crazy. You will feel a significant difference in terms of your breathing patterns, in terms of what you're the speed at what you're speaking, the speed at what you're thinking. You know, for me, here in New York City, things move very quickly. Once I hit the sauna 200 degrees and I do a couple of rounds with 38 degrees in the coal plunge and I do that three, four times, I am a completely different person. My conversation with you will be night and day, comparative to what it was 20, 30 minutes prior to that. So there's a lot of great stuff happening here and I think the fact that it's going mainstream is a tremendous win for everybody. Today our workout is cast. A lot of people won the black calves or two, just have a difficult time building and straking the calves. For one thing, I feel like a lot of people just don't train calves correctly. I see a lot of people who bounce the weights around, use too much weight or don't work out calves the way they work out in the other part of their body. If they were doing chest, you don't see people bouncing the weights around, but that's what I see when people train calves, especially on the C.D. calf raise, but still. When I train calves, I like to work them out just like I work out any other muscle part, which is making sure I get a full stretch on the muscle work and getting a really hard, full contraction at the top of each rep. This calf workout will only take about 20 minutes because we're keeping our rest time's low. So today's calf workout is three exercises. Exercise one is standing calf raise. Exercise two is seated calf raise. And exercise three is calf press on leg press machine. I recommend including these calf exercises at the end of your leg day. The first exercise is standing calf raise. We're going to start off with one one offset and four working sets. Each working set should be eight to twelve reps to failure. I do a warm upset to make sure I have proper form on the exercise. Also to make sure my foot placement is correct. The way I train my calves are pretty much the same for all my calf workouts. I want to make sure I'm stretching out my calf muscles and also getting a full hard contraction at the top of each rep. So for each rep, I want to make sure that I'm stretching out my calf muscle. Flexing as hard as I possibly can, getting that full contraction, and holding it for about a second, challenging them so that they will grow and they will get bigger and they will get stronger. There are different variations to do the standing calf raise. Today I actually did it with the Smith machine. Certain gyms do have specific standing calf raise machines and those work good as well. For the second exercise we're doing seated calf raise. We're doing one warm up and four working sets. For the working sets we're doing eight to twelve reps to failure. For the seated calf raise, you're actually going to be targeting more of the solius muscle. The solius is part of the calf muscle that is actually hit it. But by developing it helps make the calf look bigger overall. With the seated calf exercise, I don't like to use my body weight to help assist myself, but I do like to lean back slightly just so I can balance out my body weight and the weight on the machine. Exercise number three is going to be calf press on the leg press machine. We're going to be doing one warm up with four working sets. For this exercise we're doing six to ten reps to failure. Just like all my other calf workouts, I want to make sure I'm getting a full stretch at the bottom. You want to make sure that you bend your knees slightly to allow the weight to push back on your after it's been stretched out, you want to make sure that you're getting a full contraction and flex it, flex it hard. A calorie deficit doesn't just mean eat less food. You know that, right? There's only two parts that go into making a calorie deficit. The calories coming in that you eat and drink each day. And the calorie is going out that you burn each day. But the problem is when most people think about creating a deficit. They only focus on the first part of that equation, which is to eat less food. Or by thinking that the only way to increase how many calories you burn is to spend more time exercising. But that's not necessarily true. This is your TDE or a breakdown of where you burn calories in a day. And to most people's surprise, exercise is usually the smallest part. With the majority of what you do burn, coming from places that aren't the gym. So yes, you could just work out more or starve yourself. But that's probably not the smartest way to do it. And it would make a lot more sense to focus just as much on the bigger pieces. To create that deficit. Like your non-exercise movement, the other 23 hours you're not in the gym. The calories you burn from digesting the food you eat. Like eating more protein, which burns 3 to 10 times more calories being digested than carbs or fats too. And other factors that play a role in boosting the biggest part. Your BMR, like building lean muscle mass, your sleep and stress. The point is a calorie deficit isn't just if you exercise more than you can eat. It's if you're in tired life burns more than you eat. And once you look at it that way, you don't have to eat nearly as little as you think you do to make progress.

Start with a dumbbell in your right hand facing your torso. Place your left knee and your left hand on a flat bench. Keep your back straight with a slight bend in the knee and bend forward at the hips. Your torso should be almost parallel to the floor. Make sure you keep your head up. Your upper arm should be close to your torso and parallel to the floor. Your forearm should be pointed towards the floor as you hold the weights. Your upper arm should be a 90 degree angle formed between your upper arm and your forearm. This will be your starting position. Now while keeping your upper arm stationary, exhale and use your triceps to lift the weights until your arm is fully extended. Focus on moving the forearm. After a brief pause at the top contracted position, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position.

Start with a dumbbell in your right hand facing your torso. Place your left knee and your left hand on a flat bench. Keep your back straight with a slight bend in the knee and bend forward at the hips. Your torso should be almost parallel to the floor. Make sure you keep your head up. Your upper arm should be close to your torso and parallel to the floor. Your forearm should be pointed towards the floor as you hold the weights. Your shoulders should be a 90-degree angle formed between your upper arm and your forearm. This will be your starting position. Now while keeping your upper arm stationary, exhale and use your triceps to lift the weights until your arm is fully extended. Focus on moving the forearm. After a brief pause at the top contracted position, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position.

Attach a straight or angled bar to a high pulley and grab the bar with an overhand grip as shoulder width. You'll want to be standing upright with a very small forward lean. Your upper arm should be close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. Your forearm should be pointed towards the pulley as they hold the bar. This is your starting position. Now using your triceps, exhale and bring the bar down until it touches the front of your thighs and your arms are fully extended. Your upper arm should always remain stationary while your forearm's move. After holding for a brief pause in the contracted position, inhale and slowly bring the bar back down to the starting position.

Rastame Starch is a star tree's carbohydrate that comes from a certain type of corn, then when you cut it and put it on the microscope, it looks waxy. And that's why I got the name Waxi-Mane Starch. Rastame Starch actually is a slow-dad gesting, low-glaced seemic, low-inch-slim-spicic carb, and it raises blood sugar gradually, and brings it down so it's a good long-distance or long-term carb to use without a blood sugar crash. Rastame Starch because it enters the blood slowly, give you a person that are involved in long periods of training, or people that have a blood sugar crash when they take other carbs, because over a long period of time it doesn't lead to a blood sugar crash. Rastame Starch, you can use it before training, you can use it about an hour before training, to allow the slow-dad gesting carb to get into blood, or you can use it right after training, to combine it with protein, and because it leads to slow gradual insulin rise and a slow blood sugar rise, it can be something that can be used for recovery if you get a blood sugar crash from other carbs.
